Host: Pete and Susan O. are the hosts of this event.

Membership:

Joining meetup does not make you a member of our club.

Below are links to download a membership application. We have two chapters, but all our events are joined. Choose the chapter that is most convenient for you.

Colorado Springs Chapter: http://files.meetup.com/1436779/CQR-COS%20Chapter%20application.pd (http://files.meetup.com/1436779/CQR-COS%20Chapter%20application.pdf)

You are welcome to come as a guest on a limited basis, please contact the event leader for more details.

Saturday we may need to split into 2 groups. Leaving around 9:00 am
Pete will lead a ride up to Wise mountain, Montezuma, Webster pass, radical hill and red cone pass. Some of the passes may be snowed in (most likely the top of Webster) and we will have to backtrack. This will be an advanced ride for experienced riders only.

Directions:

From Hwy 9: Approximately 1 mile north of the "Round-About" on the north edge of Breckenridge is a stop light for TIGER ROAD (NOT Tiger Run)

1) Turn EAST on Tiger ROAD (aka Co Rd 6)
2) Follow Tiger Road, past the golf course - it will turn to dirt.

3) Start watching for CQR Signs. approx. 3 miles onto the dirt road, you will be making a LEFT turn on CR 354 (this road can be very rutted) If you go over the small bridge you HAVE GONE TOO FAR. travel in on this about 1 mile. There is a open space on the right, suitable for most rigs as well as some nice tenting spots. This area can fill up quickly on weekends, Please park your rig in a way that makes best use of the space available.

GPS COORDINATES for the Camp Site:

[masked], [masked]
elevation 9950

Camping: Camping is DRY with no facilities. There are Motels/Hotels in Breckenridge or Frisco and the closest gas is also in Breckenridge or Frisco. The camping area is small and often there are locals that camp there as well. So try to arrive early to secure a spot.

Potluck: We will have a potluck Dinner Saturday night at 6:00 PM, if you wish to participate please bring something to share.

Trail Width: No restrictions

Ride: Trail Difficulty in this area ranges from intermediate to Difficult.
Be prepared for all weather conditions. DOT APPROVED HELMETS ARE MANDATORY.

Maps: National Geographic Trails Illustrated #130, 131, and 132 cover this area. Also, Charles Wells has a book of the area.

Avenza MVUM maps.. White river national forest Dillon ranger district & Pike national forest South Platte Ranger District

venue.name: Housing Rights Committee of San Francisco

data.description:
~~~~~~~~~~~
Following is the text from a very important email.
If you are renting in San Francisco then this is potentially one of the most important emails you will read in 2018 thus far.
~~~~~~~~~~~
As residents of San Francisco, if we do not act right now then we will all be paying fees on top of our rent before the summer.
~~~~~~~~~~~
The time to act is now.
~~~~~~~~~~~
Volunteer:
http://hrcsf.org/volunteer/
~~~~~~~~~~~
Become a member:
http://hrcsf.org/become-a-member-today/
~~~~~~~~~~~
Get counseling:
http://hrcsf.org/counseling/
~~~~~~~~~~~
~~~~~~~~~~~
Some of the text from the email sent out by http://hrcsf.org/
~~~~~~~~~~~
Last Tuesday, almost 50 Veritas tenants, tenant advocates, Supervisor Fewer, and even a candidate for supervisor in District 6 showed up at Pine and Powell Streets for a press conference to announce new legislation that would stop landlords from passing on their mortgage and property tax to tenants.

After the press conference, tenants marched and chant to the Greentree office at 724 Pine, where we entered the lobby and 634 Powell tenants read a letter requesting a meeting to negotiate all pending operating & maintenance passthroughs across the city not covered by the legislation.

I want to acknowledge all the tenants who came out and everyone who helped out for the event, including Jeanne, Tish, and Nikki who helped with the press release, Ray who made a bunch of amazing signs (see attached photos!), Fe who led us in chants, Amina who MCed, Lenea who took photos, Charles who passed out flyers and stickers, Sandi, Engin, Theo, and Ferminita who shared their stories, and many others!

I want to highlight an important thing from the event. Right before we were set to start, Veritas contacted Supervisor Peskin's office and said that if he did not attend the event, then Veritas would sit down and negotiate all pending O&M passthroughs across the city. I spoke with Sup. Peskin's office about this decision, and Sup. Peskin decided to not attend to keep that option on the table while ensuring the press conference would still continue.

That was a VICTORY for us, as it gave us new leverage to negotiate pending passthroughs for buildings that won't benefit from the legislation!

Then, the Veritas lobbyist called Supervisor Fewer and begged us to call off the march to Greentree's office. Because of organizing this action, we suddenly gained leverage. I brought the issue to the tenants who were there, and tenants voted to continue with the press conference and march.

As a result of this action, we got leverage to negotiate other buildings' pending passthroughs AND we saw what weakens Veritas: organized tenants, public action, and media exposure!

For the legislation, it was introduced that day, April 3. We are now in a 30-day waiting period before it goes to committee for a public hearing. During this time, we need to talk with our supervisors. I'm going to send a separate email tomorrow with more info on this strategy and how to get involved, but for now, if you don't know your supervisor, please click HERE to type in your address and find your district number and supervisor. That's the first step.
~~~~~~~~~~~
Link to property map: http://propertymap.sfplanning.org/
~~~~~~~~~~~

data.description:
- deutsch weiter unten -

Come as early as 16:00 to join the cooking crew with The Real Junk Food Project: Berlin or a bit later to enjoy some informal networking, quick pitches and community building in our *Open Greeting Zone during the all-you-can-eat rescued bio food buffet. After dinner we dive into another **I.G.O. active meditative jam session...

We are looking forward to meeting with different groups and individuals to see what collaborations we can develop together.

*Pay-as-you-feel €3 - €8 :: We ask our guests to consider:
• their personal budget
• the value of their experiences in the Baumhaus
• the value of supporting the Baumhaus so that we can continue facilitating these and various other types of experiences

Program:

16:00 - 19:30 Volunteer to help cook

17:00 - Doors Open - Chill and open networking in the "Open Greeting Zone"

19:30 - All you can eat rescued bio food buffet (pay as you feel, separate from entrance) + emergent networking and hang out. (Please take home some bio veggies and bread from our food sharing basket to save it from being wasted!)

20:15 - Announcements, News, Quick Pitches (1 min)

20:30 - a short provocation. Tonight's theme :: TBD

21:00 - I.G.O. Vocal Jam Session - start moving to the back room, warming up and then jamming!

All night - please volunteer to help keep the space clean, we have no staff, just a network of people who help each other out...

*Open Greeting Zone - An area where you can feel free to walk up to any person or group, introduce yourself, be welcomed into the conversation.

**Improvisational Groove Orchestra (I.G.O.) – a fun way to experience authentic connection and community through exploring a commonly created sound space. (description & links to examples below)

----

IGO - Improvisational Groove Orchestra

We meet EVERY Thursday to listen, respond, observe and curiously play with the sounds our voices create together. Our objective is to tune into the common feeling we are developing in the present moment.

Most of what we do is with our eyes closed. This allows everyone to be very focused on only the sound space without any other distractions.

At each session we usually have more beginners rather than experienced singers; all levels and voice types are welcome. Scott will explain a few basic and intuitively understandable concepts to make it super easy to dive in and be jamming out within the first 15 minutes! It is a learning process in progress, each time balancing ourselves in volume and expression to merge into the group sound space, allowing everyone to hear and be heard, naturally developing our own musical styles.

The last times we explored further into the human sequencer game – a system where one person acts as a conductor, splitting the group into small parts, giving each small group unique impulses that than develop into one composition.

Feel most welcome to come and join us! (please be on time, there are important things to explain before beginning)

** pay as you feel, 2 - 5€ after the session

• You can find older tracks from previous IGO session in Das Baumhaus here: - • NEW! ---> https://soundcloud.com/das-baumhaus/sets/improvisational-groove-orchestra-baumhaus-23072017
• https://soundcloud.com/scott-bolden/ebb-and-flow-p2-edit-2
• https://soundcloud.com/scott-

• Here is a video showing another fun method with larger groups: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bjzmfpnZhDk

The address is Gerichtstr. 23 in the front house on the ground floor, you can walk in our door from the sidewalk. We will have drinks available.

Peace,
Scott

-------

DE

Kommen Sie schon um 16:30 Uhr zur Kochcrew mit "The Real Junk Food Project: Berlin" oder ein wenig später, um sich während des 'all-you-can-eat' geretteten Bio Food Buffets in unserer *"Open Greeting Zone" informell zu vernetzen und die Community aufzubauen. Nach dem Abendessen tauchen wir in einen weiteren **I. G. O. eine aktive meditative Jam Session....

Wir freuen uns darauf, mit verschiedenen Gruppen und Einzelpersonen zusammenzutreffen, um zu sehen, welche Zusammenarbeit wir gemeinsam entwickeln können.

Pay-as-you-feel €3 - €8:: Wir bitten unsere Gäste zu berücksichtigen:
• ihr persönliches Budget
• der Wert ihrer Erfahrungen im Baumhaus
• den Wert der Unterstützung des Baumhauses, damit wir diese und viele andere Erfahrungen weiter vermitteln können

Programm:

16:00 - 19:30 Freiwillige Helferin beim Kochen

17:00 - Türen öffnen - Chill and open networking in der "Open Greeting Zone"

19:30 - Alles, was Sie essen können, gerettetes Buffet (je nach Lust und Laune bezahlen) + auftauchendes Networking und Ausgehen. (Bitte nehmen Sie etwas Bio-Gemüse und Brot aus unserem Essenshandelskorb mit nach Hause, um es vor Verschwendung zu bewahren!

20:15 - Ankündigungen, News, Quick Pitches (1 min)

20:30 - eine kurze Provokation. Das Thema des heutigen Abends:: HOME

21:00 Uhr - I. G. O. Vocal Jam Session - gehen Sie ins Hinterzimmer, wärmen Sie sich auf und jammen Sie dann!

Die ganze Nacht hindurch - bitte meldet euch freiwillig, um den Raum sauber zu halten, wir haben kein Personal, nur ein Netzwerk von Leuten, die sich gegenseitig helfen...

Offene Grüßuzone - Ein Bereich, in dem Sie sich frei fühlen können, zu jeder Person oder Gruppe hinaufzugehen, sich vorzustellen, in das Gespräch willkommen zu heißen.

Improvisational Groove Orchestra (I. G. O.) - eine unterhaltsame Art und Weise, authentische Verbindungen und Gemeinschaft zu erleben, indem man einen gemeinsam geschaffenen Klangraum erkundet. (Beschreibung & Links zu den Beispielen unten)

----

IGO - Improvisations-Groove-Orchester

Jeden Donnerstag treffen wir uns, um zuzuhören, zu antworten, zu beobachten und neugierig mit den Klängen zu spielen, die unsere Stimmen gemeinsam erzeugen. Unser Ziel ist es, uns auf das gemeinsame Gefühl einzustellen, das wir im gegenwärtigen Moment entwickeln.

Das meiste von dem, was wir tun, ist mit geschlossenen Augen. Dadurch kann jeder Mensch ohne weitere Ablenkung auf den Klangraum fokussiert werden.

Bei jeder Session haben wir in der Regel mehr Anfänger als erfahrene Sänger; alle Level und Stimmtypen sind willkommen. Scott wird ein paar grundlegende und intuitiv verständliche Konzepte erklären, die es super einfach machen, in den ersten 15 Minuten einzutauchen und herauszufahren!

Es ist ein Lernprozess im Gange, bei dem wir uns jedes Mal in Lautstärke und Ausdruck ausbalancieren, um in den Gruppenklangraum einzugliedern, so dass jeder hören und gehört werden kann und natürlich unsere eigenen Musikstile entwickelt werden.

Die letzten Male haben wir uns weiter in das menschliche Sequenzerspiel eingearbeitet - ein System, in dem eine Person als Dirigent agiert und die Gruppe in kleine Teile zerlegt, die jeder kleinen Gruppe einzigartige Impulse geben, die sich dann zu einer Komposition entwickeln.

Fühlen Sie sich herzlich willkommen! (bitte pünktlich sein, es gibt wichtige Dinge zu erklären, bevor Sie beginnen)

"Pay as you feel", 2 - 5€ nach der Sitzung

Ältere Tracks aus der vorangegangenen IGO-Session in Das Baumhaus finden Sie hier:- https://soundcloud.com/scott-bolden/ebb-and-flow-p2-edit-2- https://soundcloud.com/scott-bolden/sets/ego-session-5-nov-13-2014 (Track 3)

Hier ist ein Video, das eine weitere unterhaltsame Methode mit größeren Gruppen zeigt: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bjzmfppnZhDk

Die Adresse lautet Gerichtstr. 23 im Vorderhaus im Erdgeschoss, können Sie in unserer Tür vom Bürgersteig aus gehen. An der Bar werden wir alle möglichen Getränke anbieten.

Peace,
Scott

Carbon 613: Measure and manage the footprint of your business/organization

Accountability is everywhere in businesses. In Finances, Human Resources, Procurement, Business Practices, but how accountable and transparent are businesses in their sustainability reporting? EnviroCentre’s Carbon 613 program provides businesses with the tools to measure and manage their carbon footprint, implement sustainability projects and be recognized for their leadership.

data.description:
The SF Bay Area Living Future Collaborative will bring together a panel of experts to share how they approach the sustainability value proposition, and how design teams can build a more effective argument for sustainability measures.

Sustainability is often seen as something that provides larger value to people and planet, but many owners and developers find that sustainable, deep green design and building also provides real returns on a project basis. This changes the narrative around sustainability from focusing on cost, to focusing on value proposition-whether the approach is in terms of property value, net present value, or capitalization rates. Cost is one of the primary drivers in the decision-making and design process for any construction project. In many cases, cost is seen as a significant barrier to implementing sustainable design. However, many organizations are instead seeing sustainable design as a business opportunity resulting in an improved ROI, an opportunity for social responsibility, and an integral part of their mission-driven models.

Thursday 12 July 2018, 5:30 to 7:30 PM
DPR Construction
945 Front Street
San Francisco, CA 94111

Price: $10. Discounts and fees may apply.

Visit the sponsor for this event for more information or Eventbrite to register. Click through to the sponsor for instructions. This event and its sponsor are not affiliated with <a>Green Making</a>. This announcement is a courtesy for our members.
data.name: The Business Case for Sustainable Design: Exploring the Value Proposition

Please join us for a presentation by Derek and Nancy Casady and learn how you can act now on climate change.
Derek and Nancy are organizers for the San Diego Climate Mobilization Coalition, part of a movement out of New York City, called The Climate Mobilization. The Climate Mobilization organization is calling for a national industrial mobilization to build a new American energy system based on Wind, Water and Solar Energy to replace fossil fuels.
Nancy is the retired General Manager of Ocean Beach People's Organic Food Co-op, an organic, vegetarian grocery store owned by 13,000 families and she is currently a Governor Brown-appointee to the California State Board of Food and Agriculture. Derek is president of the La Jolla Democratic Club and a former editor of the Los Angeles Times and of Psychology Today magazine.

There will be time for questions from the audience and light refreshments will be served.

data.description:
Conference call number: (415)[masked]

Are you an Air Miner? Trying to find focus in the din? The Climate Action Green Room is the place for you!

In March 2018, we started this bi-weekly conference call by asking the questions, What is climate change in 2018, and what are you doing about it?

This week, we continue our focus on Air Mining and carbontech.

Just in the last six months, since your organizers Impossible Labs launched airminers.org, we've seen Manylabs chart a course towards carbontech, the Center for Carbon Removal launched its Carbontech Labs, and the US federal tax code received a carbon capture deduction, called "45Q." All this - and we've barely scratched the surface of what's going on in the space.

Thanksgiving is in 5 months and now's the perfect time to practice your Why Climate Change is an Opportunity pitch for your family. Come jam on Air Mining with us and perhaps a symphony will emerge.

Looking forward to hearing you.

About the Climate Action Green Room:

It is intended to be a fire-starter. A spark! A seed! By "seeing" and hearing each other, our actions can be more coordinated, more informed, no matter where you are in the climate continuum.

In the spirit of local solutions, this is a virtual meeting that takes place on our conference line. The phone number is[masked]. It's also in the notes document (bit.ly/climatenotes), and will be shared in the comments Day-of. For those who have attended previous meetings, it's always the same number.

Want to share updates from your project in a safe space? Ask stupid questions? Learn about different opportunities to capitalize on the climate opportunity? This is your chance!

data.description:
INSCRIPTION SUR EVENTBRITE : https://bit.ly/2Jl02kC

Qui n'a jamais regardé les avis Google, Facebook, Airbnb, Tripadvisor, Amazon... avant de prendre sa décision d'achat ? Il en va de même pour vos consommateurs ou clients ! Toute personne a besoin d'avis extérieurs avant d'acheter un produit ou un service dont il n'a jamais fait l'expérience, vu ou touché. Et face aux discours de promotion de l'entreprise, ils véhiculent la vérité du consommateur (encore faut-il qu'ils soient parfaitement honnêtes !).

Le bouche-à-oreille est certainement la plus vieille pratique marketing au monde, seul véhicule de notoriété avant l'apparition des supports publicitaires. Avec le web, le bouche-à-oreille a simplement changé de forme, ou plutôt est devenu multiforme, naviguant entre le "hors ligne" et le "en ligne". Il devient alors plus puissant avec un taux de conversion important pour un coût d'acquisition par client moindre.

Le prochain atelier de Les Talents M sera animé par Nathalie Esain, consultante en expérience client. Son intervention vous permettra de comprendre comment se construit le parcours de la satisfaction client inhérente au bouche-au-oreille, les différentes formes du bouche-à-oreille (en ligne, hors ligne, positif, négatif...), les actions possibles, et ses effets sur l'entreprise, vos collaborateurs, vos ventes et l'engagement client.
Durant l'atelier, vous aurez également l'occasion d'évaluer en direct la performance de vos points de contact.

--

Des photos seront prises durant l'événement. En complétant votre inscription, vous acceptez qu'elles soient diffusées sur nos réseaux.
data.name: Bouche-à-oreille en ligne et hors ligne : ces avis qui comptent !

data.description:
Interested in permaculture, but don't know how to get more hands-on? Put off by the cost and commitment of full design courses? Want to find a space to explore, share and learn about all different aspects of this weird thing 'permaculture'?

The Permaculture Community Classroom is the answer to all of these! All you need is to come with an idea, a resource or a topic of discussion which you would like to share. If you don't have one, just come with an open mind and willingness to learn.

Whatever comes up is what we will talk about and whoever is there are the right people. It also depends a lot on what came up in the previous session.

These sessions are intended for discussion and learning, so debate and (friendly!) disagreement are encouraged. Some prior knowledge/experience of permaculture is great in order to delve deeper into the topics we come across, but all levels from ignorant to expert will be warmly welcomed.

------------------------

Why join us? Well, so far at The Permaculture Community Classroom we have collected a library of over 30 permaculture-relevant books and half a dozen DVDs, two full harddrives (2TBs!!!) of permaculture-relevant films, documents and pdf books and lots of enthusiastic, practical and smiley folk! And the resources just keep growing and growing, free for all to use of course.

This event is free to attend however we pay a small fee to rent the space we use and we are always keen to add to our library so donations are gratefully accepted but not required.

data.description:
Did you know you can become an Angel Investor in startups, investing amongst top angels and venture capitalist for as low as $100?

Join us at our monthly meetup to learn how you can start diversifiying your portfolio into startups, real estate, pre-IPO companies, and security tokens! Trying to raise for your own startup? We can help there too!

Every month we'll have presentations, panels, and live pitches from companies you can invest in ON THE SPOT from your phone.

Schedule:
6:00-7:00 Arrive/Sign-in/Networking
7:00-7:20 Pitches/Panel
7:20-7:30 Quick Break
7:30-8:00 Final Presenter

🔥 What are Angel Investors?
They are a special breed of investor that take the risk of investing in startups, early-stage businesses, and entrepreneurs they believe in.

💰 What are the average Angel Investor returns?
Investopedia reports angel investment portfolios average between 20-30%* as well as the Angel Capital Association reported their angel investors internal rate of return (IRR) over time was 27%*.

🧐 So what about the companies we work with?
One of our partners, Wefunder, just released it's 5-year returns report and since 2013 investors on its platform have earned annual unrealized returns of 53%.

In other words, if you’d invested in the deals featured on WeFunder, you could have pocketed gains of 53% each year.

Not only is that enough to double your money every 18 months or so, but it’s enough to outperform the very best Venture Capitalists in Silicon Valley…

You see, according to research firm Cambridge Associates, over the same five-year investment period, the top U.S. Venture Capitalists earned just 15% per year.

In other words, investors like you could have beaten the professionals by about 300%.

🤯 Wow... that's a lot! How do they do it?
The key to angel investing is diversification and with Newchip you can find investments starting as low as $100, allowing you to affordably build a large and diverse portfolio of your own.

Before recent regulatory changes, you used to have to invest thousands of dollars or more to be able to invest in early-stage companies but now you have the ability to invest as low as $100 apiece into companies.

🧐 How much "should I invest"?
Angels that reported 27% IRR invested at least 10% of their wealth into angel investing.

1. We can't recommend how much you invest but it should only be a % of your total investment portfolio to help manage risk in addition to other investments like- public stocks, real estate, REIT's, etc.

2. It should not be your only investment or your entire portfolio. If you invest $1,000 into one company you find on Newchip, and that's it, you are NOT diversifying. That's the exact opposite of diversification.

🤓 Why do we care so much about entrepreneurs and startups?
Entrepreneurship is the #1 driver for social impact globally, and at Newchip we’re on a mission to change the world through it. It's that simple.

🤷 So who are we?
We're a group of entrepreneurs that believe there should be better investment options than what the financial advisors that led us into the Great Recession recommend to us.

For the first time, we can all affordably invest alongside professional investors in startups, pre-IPO companies, real estate, REIT’s, and even blockchain technologies and security tokens.

This new type investing is revolutionizing how companies grow, scale, and create products. It's helping entrepreneurs connect to investors they never would have had access to and helping investors to invest in what they believe in.

💡 I've never heard of this. What do I call it?
It goes by many names: crowd investing, investment crowdfunding and equity crowdfunding. It was born from Kickstarter and Indiegogo, but instead of getting a t-shirt and thank you, you can now receive and own a slice of the companies.

data.description: What is wrong with American education? In our July meeting we will consider thought provoking ideas put forward by educationalist Sir Ken Robinson. The meeting will begin with a 19-minute video in which Professor Robinson outlines 3 principles crucial for the human mind to flourish – and how current education culture works against them. In a funny, stirring talk he tells us how to get out of the educational "death valley" we now face, and how to nurture our youngest generations with a climate of possibility. Sir Kenneth Robinson is a British author, speaker and international advisor on education in the arts to government, non-profits, education and arts bodies. He was Professor of Arts Education at the University of Warwick. In 2003 he was knighted for services to the arts. He currently resides in the U.S. The video will be followed by a discussion and sharing of wisdom which hopefully will enrich us all. Ron Rubin will lead the group. Your ideas and participation are welcome. As usual, we will meet from 6 to 9 PM upstairs at the Moonstruck Restaurant located at 449 Third Avenue at the Southeast corner of East 31st Street, New York. Please being friends and family; have dinner at 6, if you can, but all are welcome anytime. We will start the video at 7:00 PM to allow time for discussion after. Note that because this meeting is being held in a restaurant, food and adult beverage of your choice will be available for purchase. Smar10up think tank NYC will be co-hosting this meetup with the Metropolitan Humanists of New York City and several other groups.

data.description:
Because people are busy with summer plans, and I am getting this post up a week late, our next book will be a brief one: a genre-blending (part graphic novel) work by Mark Kurlansky, author of the best-selling non-fiction titles, Cod and Salt.

KIRKUS REVIEW
The author of Cod (1997) successfully provides readers with a frightening look at the looming destruction of the oceans. Brief sections in graphic-novel format follow a young girl, Ailat, and her father over a couple of decades as the condition of the ocean grows increasingly dire, eventually an orange, slimy mess mostly occupied by jellyfish and leatherback turtles. At the end, Ailat’s young daughter doesn’t even know what the word fish means. This is juxtaposed against nonfiction chapters with topics including types of fishing equipment and the damage each causes, a history of the destruction of the cod and its consequences, the international politics of the fishing industry and the effects of pollution and global warming. The final chapter lists of some actions readers could take to attempt to reverse the damage: not eating certain types of fish, joining environmental groups, writing to government officials, picketing seafood stores that sell endangered fish, etc. Whenever an important point is to be made, font size increases dramatically, sometimes so that a single sentence fills a page—attention-getting but distractingly so. While it abounds with information, sadly, no sources are cited, undermining reliability. Additionally, there are no index and no recommended bibliography for further research, diminishing this effort’s value as a resource. Depressing and scary yet grimly entertaining. (Nonfiction/graphic-novel hybrid. 10 & up)
data.name: Let's Discuss World Without Fish by Mark Kurlansky

data.description:
The Space Coast Progressive Alliance advances progressive policies at the local, state and national level through support of political candidates, education on critical issues, coordination of activities among local and state progressive organizations, and providing internet resources. We are a grassroots organization of concerned citizens who strive for domestic and international policies beneficial to the well-being and self-determination of Americans and all peoples of the world, for protection of civil and personal liberties, and for progressive environmental, economic, labor, health care, social welfare, education, foreign, and defense policies.

The Space Coast Progressive Alliance derives its ideals and principles from the Constitution and Bill of Rights of the United States.

1. We believe our government must protect all of its citizens from all forms of discrimination.
2. We believe our government must provide universal and comprehensive health care.
3. We believe our government must provide students with a high quality, free public education that respects the separation of church and state.
4. We believe our government must insure that all individuals continue to enjoy free speech, the protection and advancement of personal privacy, and a free media, even in the context of international threats.
5. We believe our government must protect our environment, preserve our natural heritage, and adopt growth policies that support an ecologically sustainable economy beneficial to citizens of the United States and the world.
6. We believe our government must adopt progressive domestic economic and labor policies that promote prosperity and social equality here and abroad.
7. We believe our government must follow a progressive foreign policy that seeks social justice, economic cooperation, peaceful conflict resolution, and economic justice for all world citizens. These goals will only be realized through multilateral cooperation and participation in international organizations and treaties.
8. We recognize threats to our national security. We believe our government must develop defense policies that are guided by a progressive foreign policy in which imperial ambitions are forsaken. We believe that an adequate yet affordable defensive military capability must be maintained.

data.description:
Join us for a thoughtful and lively discussion as we delve into Cuz: The Life and Times of Michael A. If you haven’t finished the book by the time we meet, you are still warmly invited. All view points and people of all ages are welcome in our civil discussions.

Summary from Good Reads:
Michael Alexander Allen, the baby cousin of an extended family, was first arrested at fifteen for an attempted carjacking. Tried as an adult and sentenced to thirteen years, Michael served eleven. Three years after his release, he was shot and killed. Why? Why did this gifted young man, who dreamed of being a firefighter and a writer, end up dead? Why did he languish in prison? And why at fifteen was he in an alley in South Central LA, holding a gun while trying to steal someone’s car? Cuz means both “cousin” and “because.”

Terry Gross’ interview with the author Danielle Allen https://www.npr.org/2017/09/20/552318248/cuz-examines-the-tragic-life-and-death-of-a-young-black-man-in-la

New York Times article
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/30/books/review-cuz-danielle-allen.html

————————————————
• What we'll do
We are the Young Professionals for CARE in Philadelphia. Together, we will explore topics connected to CARE’s mission, both non-fiction and fiction, covering stories from all over the world and throughout history. Our hope is that through reading these books and sharing a dialogue, we can expand our views of the world, the issues people and societies are facing, and discuss how CARE is working to affect change in the world.

What to expect:
Meeting new people who share a global perspective
Lively conversation and discussion about the book and the issues it highlights
Light refreshments, both food and drink

• What to bring
Bring a friend, if you'd like!

data.description:
Can chatbots do good in society?

Hundreds of new 'bots' are launched each day across platforms like facebook messenger, Slack, Kik, Amazon Alexa and Google Home.

Most of these are business bots, designed for marketing and profit.

But an increasing number are being created to serve a social good.

From anti-harassment bot '@talk2spot', cognitive behavioural therapist '@drwoebot' right through to '@allychatbot' - designed to help young homeless people - there is a new generation of designers who believe chatbots can serve a social good.

But can an artificial 'agent', an algorithm, really be any use to society?

Can they help alleviate loneliness? Can they really address issues of self-esteem and successfully guide people through the labyrinthine care and benefits network?

And if they can serve any kind of good, how does a social enterprise go about trying to build a chatbot from scratch?

These are some of the questions we will be addressing with three speakers at our first meetup 'bots for good'.

We hear from two of the experts at the cutting edge of chatbot design.

Accidental bot developer Steve Worswick talks about the unexpected social value of his prize-winning chatbot Mitsuku.

Botpreneur founder Jim Rowe talks us through the basic process of designing a chatbot from scratch: from where to go for information and expertise, to how much you might have to spend (if anything).

Finally entrepeneur Martin Hennessey chairs an audience led discussion with our guests and asks what, if anything, our audience would like to see from 'bots for good' in the future.

The talks will start promptly at 7pm and finish by 9pm.

There will be free drinks, snacks and some fascinating people to network with - many of whom are as ambitious as you are to find ways to change the world for the better.
data.name: Can chatbots do good?

data.description:
As of September 2017, we have been conducting the Thursday night homeless outreach successfully for almost 6 years.

*******************************************

Help out in your community by volunteering or donating. (PLEASE READ THOROUGHLY BEFORE SIGNING UP)

We would like you to know that all donations are truly appreciated however the most important part of our weekly visits to these homeless people is the interaction and conversation. They have a voice that longs to be heard even if that is as far as it goes. Our homeless friends need to know that there are people out there that have not forgotten about them, that still care and want to help them in some way.

DONATE: DRY GOODS ARE ALWAYS NEEDED (CANNED FOOD, SOUPS, PASTA, SNACKS, ETC.) SO PLEASE DONATE OR CONTACT THE EVENT HOST(S) FOR A DONATION PICKUP. THANK YOU!

VOLUNTEER: COME OUT AND HELP OUR HOMELESS BROTHERS AND SISTERS by supplying them with food, water, and clean clothes on the streets of Downtown STL. Meet us at 7pm on the corner of Locust and 15th St. We will organize the carpool to hand out the supplies we have gathered. Safety first: We always stay together in groups, travel by car together, and have a good rapport with the people we help.

We welcome your help. Please comment below and specify if you intend to bring any supplies, so we can make sure all the essentials are covered. Keep in mind that you are not obligated to bring supplies in order to participate. We are a loving group of people helping other people who are in need so please bring an open mind and an open heart.

PLEASE CONTACT LeQuisha WITH ANY QUESTIONS.

List of supplies that are always in demand (Listed in order of importance):

• Water (bottled, gallon, etc.)

• BLANKETS, sleeping bags, tents, tarps

• Candles, flashlights, lanterns

• Batteries (any size)

• Propane (small green canisters), Propane (large white canisters)

• Clothes, socks, underwear, shoes, boots, coats, jackets

• Pre-packaged foods, pop-top canned goods, other non-perishable food items, snack food items

• Soap, deodorant, baby wipes, toilet paper, feminine hygiene products, first aid kits, hand sanitizer, towels

•LOVE, COMPASSION, PRAYERS (we can never have too much)

Volunteers are encouraged to reach out to local businesses for meal donations for our friends in need. Many restaurants and other businesses are happy to contribute. Also, volunteers have found success in conducting drives at church, work, etc. to acquire donations of supplies.

***Also, if you know of businesses/companies who are currently hiring for employment or job fairs please share this information on the discussion thread below.***

THANK YOU !!!

**Remember, please update your RSVP if you can no longer join us.**

*******************************************

data.description:
This is a meeting for music show hosts and those who want to DJ on Radio. Meeting locations change, so email [masked].

How much local music do you hear on the San Diego airwaves?
Corporate radio would have you believe that we live in a local music desert!

The truth is that San Diego has a vibrant community of local musicians and artists, but commercial radio has all but ignored local talent. Not surprising because many San Diego stations are programmed out of corporate headquarters with the same playlist as doled out in Idaho and Maine. Shame on them!

KNSJ 89.1 FM intends to revolutionize the airwaves. KNSJ is community radio and wants to change the cultural landscape with alternative programming while supporting local artists and their listeners. KNSJ pledges to play more local bands and artists than all the rest of San Diego's radio stations combined.

KNSJ intends to focus on creative and socially conscious music. John Legend, in accepting the Oscar for best song, reminded us that "it's an artist’s duty to reflect the times we're in,"... " the struggle for justice is right now." KNSJ wants to create a cultural revolution of hope, of optimism, of love and ire... inspiring collective action to save the planet. While some music is created as escapism, other music becomes anthems for consciousness and change.

KNSJ’s Local Music Summits bring together local DJs, music producers, musicians and show hosts to talk about transforming the airwaves with new local radio shows and podcasts. KNSJ’s current local shows include Sonic Sundowner with Benjamin Cossel and Train of Thought Podcast with Gill Sotu. The expectation is that the Local Music Summits will spawn a dozen other music shows from hip-hop to folk, reggae to Blues, Latin, Asian, African and Worldbeat. Many of these programs will feature interviews and insights into the musicians and their creative process as they minister through their music. The expectation is that more local music on the air will result in a growing appreciation of local cultural treasures and in time will result in larger audiences allowing for more musicians being able to sustain themselves through their craft. KNSJ looks towards the day when it becomes a clearing house for local music. KNSJ expects to host live music on the air, and co-sponsor concerts and festivals where there is a convergence of many of the performing arts including spoken word and dance. These music events will in turn support the community radio station, which depends on individual donations for its future growth.

Local musicians wanting to get their talent on the air can post their music on KNSJ at http://knsj.org/music/

Listen Up: No matter where you are you can listen to KNSJ.org or use the TuneIn radio app or find us on iTunes.

For more information contact: [masked] or call[masked].

data.description:
Wake Audubon BIRDWALK: Fred Fletcher Park, 730 Washington Street, Raleigh, NC: FRIDAY, JULY 13, 2018 from 8:00 a.m. SHARP and ending by 9:30 a.m. Please allow extra time for commuter traffic.Note parking instructions below.

Meet at the MARSH OVERLOOK, which is the lowest part of the park; park on Washington Street near Glenwood Avenue intersection. Parking is free on that road. You must park within 12 inches of the curb. (Please note that Fred Fletcher Park has several entrances. Read the parking signs CAREFULLY so that your car is not ticketed.)
I drive a 2013 Gray Nissan Rogue. Back plate 0PTMYSTC, front plate says "His Eye Is On The Sparrow".
Fred Fletcher Park is a good beginner's birdwalk: paved walkways and a short walk with several habitats, and birds that tend to be used to humans. But it MIGHT not be worth driving a long way for this park, unless you are going to head to the downtown museums or drive over to Mid Pines and Yates Mill afterwards (I have a commitment at 9:30).
Fred Fletcher Park has a VERY SMALL marsh and thicket, plus some mowed fields with trees and shrubs. Fred Fletcher Park might give us a surprising number of birds for an urban park.

Checklist for July walk in 2017:
https://ebird.org/view/checklist/S38130464

Leader: Erla Beegle; [masked] or text/call her at[masked]
NOTE: There is only a portapotty at this park -- please plan accordingly (Starbucks and MacDonalds nearby on Peace just west of Glenwood, but you have to drive there, so allow extra time.)

data.description:
Nearly half of the solid waste produced globally is organic or biodegradable. Much of it ends up in landfills where it produces the greenhouse gas methane, which is up to 34 times more powerful than carbon dioxide over a century! But processed correctly, we can create valuable fertilizer, sequester carbon, and produce usable biogas.

Since Sonoma Compost shut down in 2015, our compost has been shipped out of the county. But now there is a new compost facility being planned for Sonoma County!

The Sonoma County Waste Management Agency unanimously recommended that Renewable Sonoma be selected as the future municipal organics processing and composting company. Their plan is to build a state of the art composting facility that includes the generation of renewable energy!

Join us as we get a sneak peek inside the plans for this exciting new facility!

Our monthly Climate Chats are brought to you Free by WORK Petaluma!

Bios:
Leslie Lukacs is a pioneer in zero waste with 21 years of experience influencing waste reduction and reuse in California. She specializes in the design and implementation of comprehensive sustainability programs for large venues, and events throughout the nation.

Roy Alper has 30 years of experience in the development, regulation and financing of alternative energy systems. He is an attorney with extensive experience in negotiating agreements for renewable and waste-fueled projects, including feedstock supply and fuel amendment agreements, offtake agreements, wastewater discharge and solids disposal agreements, obtaining environmental and land use approvals and in leading project development from conception to operation.
data.name: Climate Chat: A New Compost Facility for Sonoma County!

data.description:
In the deliziosa aroma of fresh vegetables and toppings of gourmet pizza italiano, join the Phoenix Philanthropists, as we escape to Italy in the authentic pizza kitchen at St. Vincent de Paul to create scrumptious gourmet pizzas for those most in need. Volunteer pizzaioli will prepare delectable toppings, including fresh vegetables and meats, roll the original-recipe pizza dough, and help make the mouth-watering pizza pies. This program, spearheaded and developed by ASU professor, Dr. Phil Mizzi, and influenced by one of the top Italian pizzaioli in the United States, producing an average of 120 gourmet pizzas each Friday, was designed as a healthy and economical solution to enhance the quality of meals and promote the dignity of guests through the quality of service and the care and compassion of volunteers. The pizzas are all made in the kitchen at St. Vincent de Paul's Main Campus, then distributed alternately each Friday between two of SVdP's Phoenix dining rooms (including the on-site Family Dining Room). The only thing missing from the extensive menu of Salami, Creamy Roasted Red Pepper Sauce, Asparagus, Shiitaki Mushrooms, Salami, Arugula, Cherry Tomatoes, Basil, Corn, Pancetta, Roasted Garlic, Blue Cheese, and so much more, is you! So grab your spice rack of love, energy, good fun, and cheer, and join us in the cucina! Together, in a very fun and high-energy environment, we will cook up a magnifico & deliziosa difference for families and individuals struggling most in our community.

DUTIES
May include, but not limited to
Cut, chop, mix pizza toppings
Roll pizza dough
Prepare & cook pizzas
Box and load pizzas for distribution
Clean kitchen
Assist in on-site serving, if needed

FREE DINNER
After a wonderful evening of making a difference, volunteers are welcome to enjoy their delicious gourmet creations for a relaxing dinner with the great team.

ATTIRE GUIDELINES
Please wear your Phoenix Philanthropists T-Shirt (http://thephoenixphilanthropists.org/t-shirts/) or other comfortable clothing that you don't mind getting splashed with a little yummy authentic Italian sauce, and comfortable closed-toed shoes (no heels, tank tops, open midriff, low-cut tops or short-shorts).

AGE RESTRICTIONS
The minimum age to volunteer at this event is 14, and a parent or guardian must accompany volunteers under 16. All volunteers under 18 must have a completed St. Vincent de Paul Waiver signed by a parent or guardian. (See St. Vincent de Paul Waiver below.)

ST. VINCENT de Paul
When you arrive please sign in at the security desk. If you are under 18, a guardian signature must be included.

PARKING & ENTRANCE
To get to the entrance in the North Parking Lot, from Watkins, go north on 3rd Drive and turn left into the parking lot at the PINK PILLARS. The lobby is located at the other set of PINK PILLARS.

CHECK-IN & LOCKERS
Check in with Security who will provide a badge (paper sticker) to be worn while volunteering. Print your FIRST NAME ONLY on the badge. For protection of your personal belongings, please ask the guard for a locker key.

ATTENDANCE POLICY: Please note Phoenix Philanthropists does have an attendance policy. We understand that plans change and emergencies come up. If you RSVP YES, but can no longer attend, PLEASE change your RSVP ASAP. Please note that we do have an attendance policy. Our charity partners rely on us to attend when we say we will and our attendance policy is intended to ensure we can meet our charity partners' expectations. Please give a minimum of 24 hours notice for this event before canceling. No Call/No Shows will be recorded, and after 3 No Call No Shows/3 months or 6 No Call No Shows/year, you will be removed from the Phoenix Philanthropists MeetUp. Please understand this policy is not intended to penalize our philanthropists, but to ensure we maintain good relationships with our charity partners and can give the most back to our community.

About St. Vincent de Paul Dining Rooms: St. Vincent de Paul, with one of the largest industrial dining rooms in the Southwest, provides meals in five dining rooms throughout the valley to help those in need. Serving Central and Northern Arizona, over 1.2 million meals a year are provided to hungry and malnourished families and individuals, through St. Vincent de Paul's dining rooms, kitchen, and food bank. For more information go to http://www.stvincentdepaul.net

data.description:
The National Arboretum Canberra features 94 forests of rare, endangered and symbolic trees from around Australia and the world. Many of the trees are still young but two of the forests are over 100 hundred years old. Over 44,000 trees from over 100 countries are growing across the huge 250 hectare (618 acre) site, making it one of the world's largest living collections of rare, endangered and significant trees.

The Village Centre is the first point of arrival at the Arboretum, offering an elegant and memorable welcome. This award-winning, architect-designed building with panoramic views over Canberra provides a variety of high-quality visitor services and facilities, including a restaurant, cafe, gift shop, information hub, and the National Bonsai and Penjing Collection.

Share a cuppa and a chat to get to know others in the group. After we will visit the Bonsai's. It's all indoors but feel free to rug up and go for a walk outside through the forests if you are interested.

Costas will be the contact for this meeting. He can be reached on[masked] if you have any questions on the day or are running late and need to find the group.

If you are renting in San Francisco then this is potentially one of the most important emails you will read in 2018 thus far.
~~~~~~~~~~~
As residents of San Francisco, if we do not act right now then we will all be paying fees on top of our rent before the summer.
~~~~~~~~~~~
The time to act is now.
~~~~~~~~~~~
Volunteer:
http://hrcsf.org/volunteer/
~~~~~~~~~~~
Become a member:
http://hrcsf.org/become-a-member-today/
~~~~~~~~~~~
Get counseling:
http://hrcsf.org/counseling/
~~~~~~~~~~~
~~~~~~~~~~~
Some of the text from the email sent out by http://hrcsf.org/
~~~~~~~~~~~
Last Tuesday, almost 50 Veritas tenants, tenant advocates, Supervisor Fewer, and even a candidate for supervisor in District 6 showed up at Pine and Powell Streets for a press conference to announce new legislation that would stop landlords from passing on their mortgage and property tax to tenants.

After the press conference, tenants marched and chant to the Greentree office at 724 Pine, where we entered the lobby and 634 Powell tenants read a letter requesting a meeting to negotiate all pending operating & maintenance passthroughs across the city not covered by the legislation.

I want to acknowledge all the tenants who came out and everyone who helped out for the event, including Jeanne, Tish, and Nikki who helped with the press release, Ray who made a bunch of amazing signs (see attached photos!), Fe who led us in chants, Amina who MCed, Lenea who took photos, Charles who passed out flyers and stickers, Sandi, Engin, Theo, and Ferminita who shared their stories, and many others!

I want to highlight an important thing from the event. Right before we were set to start, Veritas contacted Supervisor Peskin's office and said that if he did not attend the event, then Veritas would sit down and negotiate all pending O&M passthroughs across the city. I spoke with Sup. Peskin's office about this decision, and Sup. Peskin decided to not attend to keep that option on the table while ensuring the press conference would still continue.

That was a VICTORY for us, as it gave us new leverage to negotiate pending passthroughs for buildings that won't benefit from the legislation!

Then, the Veritas lobbyist called Supervisor Fewer and begged us to call off the march to Greentree's office. Because of organizing this action, we suddenly gained leverage. I brought the issue to the tenants who were there, and tenants voted to continue with the press conference and march.

As a result of this action, we got leverage to negotiate other buildings' pending passthroughs AND we saw what weakens Veritas: organized tenants, public action, and media exposure!

For the legislation, it was introduced that day, April 3. We are now in a 30-day waiting period before it goes to committee for a public hearing. During this time, we need to talk with our supervisors. I'm going to send a separate email tomorrow with more info on this strategy and how to get involved, but for now, if you don't know your supervisor, please click HERE to type in your address and find your district number and supervisor. That's the first step.
~~~~~~~~~~~
Link to property map: http://propertymap.sfplanning.org/
~~~~~~~~~~~

SOS Ocean Clean Up is excited to announce the 2nd annual Stoked On Salt Ocean Conservation Day on Friday, July 13th, 4:00PM - 10:00pm at the Jaco Pastorius Park located at 4000 N. Dixie Hwy., Oakland Park, FL 33334.

Due to the overwhelmingly positive feedback of last year's event, Team SOS has expanded and partnered with the City of Oakland Park.

• 50 Ocean Conservation Booths
• Local Ocean Artists
• Kids Fun & Crafts
• Food Booths - Drinks
• Live music by the Caribbean Waves Steel Drum Band
• Live culinary shows
• Free Give-Aways
• Free Movie On the Lawn "DEEP"

This free event is not only fun, but an educational program for the entire family that will help bring awareness to our ocean in efforts to preserve and protect our living coral reef ecosystems.

50 Ocean/Marine Conservation groups will come out to engage in outreach with the general public about issues that could be addressed on a local level - which we so desperately need:
CORALS - MANATEES - LIONFISH - BEACH/OCEAN DEBRIS - SHARKS - SEA TURTLES - MANTA RAYS - WHALES - LOBSTERING - WATER QUALITY - WILDLIFE RESCUE - FISHING REGULATIONS - OCEAN SAFETY and more.

data.description:
Give the gift of a warm meal and become inspired by serving it to the great men reestablishing their lives at the Allentown Rescue Mission. You will be very glad you did afterwards. We have been doing this activity over a year and it has been a great event for everyone who has volunteered from Lehigh Valley People Helping People. Come back or join us for the first time. We welcome all with open arms and hearts!

Requirements:

:-) Bring a food item(s) from the list below.

:-) Show up at the Allentown Rescue Mission from 4-6 pm and join in socializing with our group members and serving our meal to the men at the mission.

* We are hoping to have 8 members make and serve food on July 13th and an additional 3 or 4 members who will make food and drop off at the Mission prior to our dinner.
*Please email Mike H. what you will bring. The more food the better, nothing goes to waste.

Food Items Needed:

8 large trays of baked ziti (easy to make...ground beef/pork/turkey, 2 boxes of ziti noodles, tomato sauce, cheese, etc.).

45 slices/pieces of garlic bread

45 deserts (cupcakes, brownies, donut, Tasty Cake type snacks, etc.)

Here is the scoop:

Arrive at 4 pm at the Allentown Rescue Mission with your food for dinner. Your food items should only need to be reheated at the Mission. Completely bake/cook before bringing the food item.

If anyone wants to bring any table decorations for the cafeteria, notes of encouragement, or play an instrument or sing while the men are dining, this is very welcome by the ARM staff. You are welcome to join the men for dinner. Each has his own story of life's journey into homelessness then rehabilitation through the Mission. However, this is all optional, most of us just come with a meal and serve.

4 pm - 5 pm Our MeetUp group assembles in a room the ARM provides us and we enjoy talking and socializing with each other, helping out the ARM kitchen staff to set up the meal, etc.

5 pm - 6 pm Serving time...we take turns behind a cafeteria serving line. As residents filter through the line in a very organized manner, we fill plates with food and put them on top of the station for the men to put on their tray as they head to their dining room with ARM staff to enjoy dinner. Residents are very appreciative and well organized by the ARM staff.

6 pm Driving home with a great feeling and a smile on our collective faces and in our hearts!

If you cannot attend and are willing to make food to drop off at the ARM on July 13th, that is also appreciated. Just message me (Mike H.) and let me know what you will drop off for our dinner. When you drop off your food donation, just mention it is for dinner with Lehigh Valley People Helping People.

Please no open toe shoes. Hair nets and aprons are provided by ARM staff.

This is a really great event...hope you can make it...everyone who has done this MeetUp has really seemed to enjoy the experience. Sign up, come out, you will be glad you did! :)
data.name: Make Food or Make Food and Serve Dinner @ The Allentown Rescue Mission

data.description:
Tickets available for purchase: http://www.eagxaustralia.com/

EAGxAustralia 2018 is a conference for people who want to do good, better. Learn about and discuss the latest ideas in the field of Effective Altruism, share new research, familiarise yourself with core concepts, and coordinate on global projects with experts in creating impact.

Effective Altruism uses evidence and careful analysis to find the very best causes to work on and then help you identify how to do the most good you can, with the time and money you have.

The conference, on the theme of Stay Curious, is a two-day inspiring, immersive experience featuring a diverse set of experts all primed to help us tackle the biggest issues in Effective Altruism via practical workshops and engaging sessions. Get to grips with cause areas such as global poverty, existential risk, and animal suffering. You’ll take away actionable advice for developing for-purpose business and making better life choices.

EAGxAustralia is part of the Effective Altruism Global conference series. It is the fourth annual EAGxAustralia conference.
data.name: EAG x Australia 2018

data.description:
TransitieCinema organizes July 13 the screening of "Speed - in search of lost time"

SYNOPSIS:
It’s a paradox. Never before have we worked more efficiently. Never before have we saved time with more sophisticated technologies. But nearly everyone feels they don’t have enough time.

Florian Opitz tries to track down the reasons for our lack of time and the constant acceleration of our lives. He reveals a disturbing picture of a civilisation that has disposed of all brake systems and goes blindly for unlimited and eternal growth - no matter what the consequences. But Opitz also tries to find the good life. In the niches of the global capitalism he discovers alternatives to the rat race.

SCHEDULE:
18.00 TransitieCinema Dinner by Juni Café in Het Nutshuis
19.30 Screening "Speed - in search of lost time" by TransitieCinema
21.00 Workshop, drinks and informal discussion!

NOTE:
* Admission to the MOVIE is for FREE (but we appreciate donations!)
* Make sure to ARRIVE ON TIME, the doors are closed when the movie starts or the venue is at full capacity.
* The DINNER is vegan and can be reserved online at nutshuis.nl (you can also join without a reservation)
* The movie and event are in ENGLISH (but we try to accommodate for Dutch too)
data.name: TransitieCinema: Speed - in search of lost time

data.description:
When studying prehistoric cultures in the American Southwest it is hard not to see the connections different cultures brought to each other. In this Free (asking for donation) lecture you are invited out to hear how connected Southwestern cultures were to cultures in Mesoamerica. We will discuss the following:

Mesoamerican archaeology
Southwestern archaeology
Archaic, Hohokam, Anasazi, Olmec, Mayan, Aztec, and Teotihuacan cultures
Trade and influences
Ideas and the sharing of values
Spiritual belief systems
Where Hohokam came from
Material technologies
Human sacrifice
New findings and data
and much more

We will examine actual artifacts from Mesoamerica and the Southwest and talk about the importance of each.
If you are interested in archaeology, we highly recommend attending this lecture.

IMPORTANT BELOW

When? This class will be held on Friday July 13th from 6:00pm - 7:00pm. Of course, you are not required to stay the entire length.

Where? Meet at the main parking lot by the grass field at Watson Lake. There is a $3.00 entrance fee, but it is a beautiful place with cool shade! Look for the BLACK JEEP with a white rounded sticker on the back.

How much? Free! We will have a donation jar and donations help keep us funded.

What to bring? All class tools and stone materials are provided. Bring water.

What if I have to cancel? In order for us to run our meetup group proficiently, we rely on you. We love sharing information and ancestral knowledge. However, it is very difficult when members sign up and don't attend. Please, we ask if you have to change your plans, make sure you cancel your attendance for this class.

Finally, I look forward to working with you all again!

- Jeff Martin
www.PrimitiveLifeways.com
data.how_to_find_us: Meet in the main parking lot by the big grass field. Look for the black Jeep

data.description:
Join the Coalition to Protect SLO County for a film night fundraiser! All funds generated will go toward the work of the coalition to ban new oil drilling and ban all fracking. Tickets are between $10-$20, see ticket link for details and to RSVP for limited available seating. Food will be available for purchase!

ABOUT THE FILM: If a crime is committed in order to prevent a greater crime, is it forgivable? Is it, in fact, necessary? THE RELUCTANT RADICAL is an intimate portrait of climate activist Ken Ward. Ken breaks the law as a last resort and with great trepidation, to fulfill what he sees as his personal obligation to future generations. The film follows Ken through a series of civil disobedience direct actions, culminating with his participation in the coordinated action that shut down all the U.S. tar sands oil pipelines on October 11, 2016. Facing 20 years in prison for his actions, the film reveals both the personal costs and also the fulfillment that comes from following one’s moral calling.

“There are many fronts in the vast climate fight; this film highlights the personal struggles and victories of one daring path.” -Bill McKibben, Climate Advocate and Founder of 350.org

“He was told he was crazy, but crazy is sitting idly by as disaster for young people is knowingly locked in.” -Dr. James Hansen, Climate Scientist

Coalition to Protect SLO County
Paid for by CoProSLOCo FPPC #[masked]
data.name: Film Screening Fundraiser: The Reluctant Radical

data.description:
Meet up! It takes a village, to get back on track.

The goal is this, bring together minds who can contribute and share skills toward growing a brighter future.

This means, I’ve got plant knowledge and other various experience, I need financial savvy folks, marketing savvy folks, people with municipal experience, mothers, fathers, thinkers, inspired people who would be into creating.

One of the goals of the business Home Grown Edible Landscaping and Nursery is to expose people to the fruits of what could be their labor.
One of the ways of doing that is by implementing food forests and edible landscapes in public parks. How do we do that? By planning, scheming, understanding economics and swaying the public perspective on the outdoors as being work, to the outdoors as being the grocery store.
Our nature is wild, we have been tamed and subdued for too long. Let us create and change the future, rather than wallow and critique the present.

This is just the beginning of the conversation. It could be nice to sit by the fire and delve deeper.

Feedback welcome, comments and ideas are free game.

data.description:
Have you ever heard of Permaculture and wanted to learn more ? Do you have a passion for growing your own food, or sustainability? This FREE lecture and group discussion held by the School of Permaculture is a great opportunity to learn, network, and gain an introduction certificate to Permaculture. A one and a half hour presentation by a member of the School of Permaculture team will be given followed by a suburban permaculture food forest garden tour. A very positive and open discussion about anything related is encouraged and usually follows (we promote networking!). Once completed you can obtain an Introduction into Permaculture certificate that states you have completed an Introduction into Permaculture class and can be used for continuing education as well. The location is at a Plano, TX residence with a backyard full of permaculture goodies including: rain water harvesting, gray water bed filtration and use, suburban food forestry, serious composting, strategic permaculture gardening and more.

For any questions contact us via e-mail at [masked]

data.description:
Are you struggling with stress and anxiety? You are not alone. With our political scene, relationships, money, career and all the other situations that come with life it’s good if we have all the tools we can gather to support us through trying times. EFT is one of those powerful tools. EFT stands for Emotional Freedom Techniques. Also know as tapping. We are energy in a fleshly package and good energy flow is necessary for our well being. Everything that happens to us in life is energy. That energy can be positive or negative. The good energy flows through our system smoothly and doesn’t get stalled. If the energy is negative or low it can get stuck in our bodies and cause emotional issues or even physical manifestations. That is where EFT comes in. While being tuned in to a negative emotion and tapping on certain points on the body a signal is sent through the energy system and essentially cleans it out. That signal also goes to the fight or flight center in the brain and shuts it down or calms it. You in turn get relief.

Come and see how it works at my workshop at: $15 Cash at 🚪 door

data.description:
We're heading for the beach this month -- to check out the health of our waters, sea life and human life. Plastics and other refuse decompose slowly or not at all. And huge amounts of these discards accumulate in our oceans, streams -- and blood streams -- polluting terribly. Come as you are in cool summer cut offs-- to wade with us into such problems -- and dive with us into the solutions. We’ll be showing the film “Plastic Paradise” (http://plasticparadisemovie.com/) and discussing water resource issues and ways to Reduce, Reuse, and Recycle with resource Dave Gorman.

Save this Part for Year-Round Reference: 2nd Friday Nights are for Just Views!

Just Views programs start at 7:20 pm, are sponsored by the DuPage Peace through Justice Coalition and are held in Naperville IL at the DuPage Unitarian Universalist Church at 1828 Old Naperville Road.

Directions: If coming from east or west on route I-88, exit at Naperville Road onto Freedom Drive. Turn left (East) onto Diehl Road and continue across Naperville Road/Naper Blvd, and then turn left/north at the first street (Old Naperville Road). The Unitarian Church is down one block on your right. Note: For other route options and a map, see church website: www.dupageuuchurch.org. The church phone is 630/[masked].

Our timely issues programs are nonpartisan, open to the public, and free -- no reservations required. Parking is free, too. Just Views shows great films about matters vital to social and economic justice on the second Friday of each month throughout the year. View and then share views from different vantages with citizens attending and invited resource persons. Each night is a stimulating, informal, stand-alone program. Join the multilogue!

To receive Just Views meeting notices via e-mail, join our new Just Views & Diversity Dinners group on www.meetup.com and find DuPage Peace Through Justice Coalition on Facebook. You can also find meeting notices on our website at http://www.dupagepeacethroughjustice.org/. Please mark your calendars ahead for the second Friday of every month, share these notices, and bring friends! Just Views Director is sociologist Stephanie Hughes 630/[masked]; Associate Director is Carol Tritschler 630/[masked].

Kick off the Minnesota Bat Festival with Science Night at the Minnesota Valley National Wildlife Refuge Bloomington Education and Visitor Center, 3815 American Blvd. East.

Science Night will be led by a team of bat experts from the Minnesota DNR and U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, who will share high-tech tools used to monitor bat activity.

Scientists will also attempt to capture and release bats for an up close view of these intriguing nocturnal mammals while demonstrating techniques used to study them.

Bring mosquito repellent and a flashlight or headlamp and wear suitable footwear.

The Minnesota Bat Festival will be held July 14 from 9 a.m.-3:30 p.m. Visit the event page here: https://www.facebook.com/events/224385758292933/

data.description:
Demitasse performing at Confluence is the first of a series of “Concerts at the Confluence” presented by the San Antonio River Foundation.

FREE CONCERT at SUNSET! Lucky Friday the 13th.

So much is happening in Demitassse world. As many of you know, Demitasse, is the smallest of bands, just myself and Joe Reyes. We typically play as a duo, with a starkly minimal setup. Two acoustic guitars and our two voices.

But on Friday the 13th of July we promise a different set up. For nearly the first time ever, Demitasse will play as a full band. Accompanied by Odie (Buttercup) on bass, we will march nearly into rock territory. This band, what I'm calling the Demitasse Good Times Band, is devastatingly capable. With Chris Maddin, former Glassnote recording artist, on piano and backing vocals, the songs will have a piano-drenched mellowness that will make you smile. Dane Rousay joins on drums, and his soft style is perfectly suited for Demitasse. And of course, Odie brings it full circle and grounds us. It's a fantastic band full of crack musicians: I couldn't be more excited.

We will begin our performance at sunset. It is free. All ages are welcome. There is limited parking on site, so you may want to park on the street, or walk or cycle to the park. Come and bring some folding chairs or a blanket and non-alcoholic drinks. We preview our new album.
data.name: Concerts at the Confluence, feat. Demitasse

data.description:
Hi.  If you are using the Meetup mobile app on your phone, look down a few lines below and tap the red-colored "Read more" to expand the description.

TAP THIS ---------

If you are using a computer or laptop/notebook, then you should be fine.

Okay, everybody should now be able to see the full description on their screen.

Reminder for everyone:  If Meetup sends too many emails, then look at the bottom of their email and click Unsubscribe or Manage your settings or account page.

Recommended for anyone new to this group or volunteering for the first time: 

www.meetup.com/LAVolunteer/events/[masked]

____________________________________________

Note:  To help me save time, this will be automatically added to the calendar once a month.  If the title includes "[check date]" then it means the date needs to be confirmed. I'll try my best to update in advance.

https://www.corazondevida.org/events

____________________________________________

FAQ

Q:  Why isn't the address posted?

A:   I don't want anyone to show up (without registering & paying) to find out the bus is full.  So if anyone is serious about attending, read their event page for info/details and instructions on how to register.  www.corazondevida.org/events

Q:  What if the bus is full?

A:  The bus has limited # of seats and accommodates people from LA, OC, and SD.  If other people registered before you, and there's no more room, try signing up for a future trip.  www.corazondevida.org/events

Q:  Is fundraising required?

A:  Corazon de Vida is a charity/non-profit, so financial donations help them support the orphanages.  These bus trips help them raise $.  I could be wrong, but I don't think anybody can force you to donate $, so although their website & emails may encourage fundraising, it's ultimately your choice to contribute or not.

Q:  Can children attend?

A:  Corazon de Vida's answer:

"We do encourage families to attend our trips to visit the orphanages. 7 or older is recommended, younger is OK but depends on maturity level and ability to spend time in bus and possible 1+ hour border wait. Each attendee must pay $50 bus fee and needs valid passport to attend."

http://www.cctv-america.com/2016/06/04/family-volunteering-a-willingness-to-help 

https://mommypoppins.com/kids/visiting-a-mexican-orphanage-with-la-kids-corazon-de-vidas-family-trips

_______________________________________

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zm4zUE7ppRI

www.corazondevida.org/events.html

Usually one Saturday a month, Corazon de Vida visits children at an orphanage in Mexico (in or near Tijuana). 

They support over 10 orphanages, so each month usually is at a different orphanage.

This 1-day trip is a unique event and involves traveling to another country, so please read carefully all their details and requirements.

The cost to participate is $50, which covers "transportation, lunch, and craft project." 

There are 3 pick-up (and drop-off) locations to choose from:  Los Angeles, Irvine, and San Diego. 

Trips during January to November are usually on 1 bus, but for December, sometimes 3 - 4 buses are used to visit more orphanages for a special holiday visit.

Due to distance and multiple stops, the majority of the day is spent on the bus.  The approximate time spent at the orphanage is about 3 hours or less.  It's up to you to decide if it's worth the $ and time. 

Personally, I've gone a few times and it was an eye-opening and heart-warming experience.  The kids are fun to play & interact with. 

Speaking Spanish is not required.  Being Mexican, Latino, or Hispanic is not required either.  The kids are accustomed to visitors of all backgrounds.

_______________________________________

If nobody else signs up from this group, other volunteers who attend are usually friendly.  During the bus ride, you should have an opportunity to talk with others sitting nearby.

A friend named Renata frequently goes, so if anyone doesn't want to go alone, feel free to ask if she is going this month or look for her on the bus:

www.meetup.com/SoCalVolunteers/members/[masked]

_______________________________________

Since this is in Mexico, having a U.S. passport and/or other government approved, legal identification & documentation is required for re-entering the country. 

To reiterate, this event occurs in Mexico...a driver's license is NOT acceptable for re-entry at the border.  Please check your passport (or other id) has not expired.

www.cbp.gov/travel/us-citizens/western-hemisphere-travel-initiative

www.dhs.gov/how-do-i/cross-us-borders

_______________________________________

TV & movies can portray Mexico in a distorted and inaccurate manner.  Without a doubt, after crossing the border, what you'll see is distinct and different from America/California.  Feeling nervous or apprehensive is totally understandable.  If it helps, CDV has successfully and safely done these monthly bus trips for many years without incident.  They are pretty organized and well-managed, so if anyone decides to go, they'll take care of you.

_______________________________________

To sign up, go to www.corazondevida.org/events

and click on "VIEW EVENT" for the respective date for more info/details and instructions on how to register and pay.

Redundant reiteration:  Signing up here on Meetup is insufficient. If anyone wants to participate, registering with CDV and paying in advance is necessary.

data.description:
Activities for this meetup:

1. Introduction of aquatic plants in the lake
2. Filling rat holes and covering tree bases with silt
3. Spreading awareness
4. Making saplings of aquatic plants

What you should bring: - We discourage the culture of use and throw. So, bringing a bottle of water from home is advised. - Bring loads of enthusiasm. - Also bring at least one new volunteer! :)

NEAREST METRO STATION: Rajendra Place

GOOGLE MAPS LOCATION: https://www.google.com/maps?q=28.6458967,77.1786167&z=17&hl=en ---

ABOUT THIS PROJECT: Delhi has 100s of water bodies! Or we should say had. Because most of them are nearly dead. They are dumped with garbage and religious offerings and their surface has algae. These factors lead to low levels of dissolved oxygen, making marine life unsustainable. Moreover, it leads to other problems like breeding of mosquitoes. One such victim is Prasad Nagar Lake. Yes, the same place we had our nature walk. Guess what's our new project? Revival of Prasad Nagar Lake. Yes, this is a long term project and we have government support too! As a part of this whole project we will clear all plastic and other waste lying at the bottom of this lake. And we will later introduce water plants such a lotus and water lilies in it. Introduction of aquatic plants is vital for the lake's health. It'll ensure optimum dissolved oxygen levels for other aquatic life such as a variety of fish. It'll also help keep the lake naturally clean and prevent any mosquito breeding. So, let's join hands to do something big, something very interesting!
data.name: Revival of Prasad Nagar Lake - Week 11

data.description:
Invictus Dragon Boat Club Racer's Practice:

For anyone new to the sport, I would recommend reviewing the attached video. This is great to show some quick technique for the proper dragon boat stroke, you can also find many other videos on YouTube.com.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-IL8bGKKICc

This is a group for anyone that is interested in recreational dragon boat or SUP racing. All fitness levels are welcome, training is provided. The team has dragon boat practice twice a week (Tues 6:30 pm and Saturday 8:30 am) at Rick's on the River in Tampa. The strive to particpate in charity benefit races throughout the Florida area. The team is also partnered with Keep Tampa Bay Beautiful (KeepTampaBayBeautiful.org). We particpate in a few different events with KTBB yearly, are members of their Ambassadors Program. Invictus is also the 1st Team/Organization in Tampa to adopt a part of the Hillsborough Shoreline for quarterly clean ups. The shoreline clean ups consist of picking up litter on foot from the North Bridge to Columbus Bridge on foot, along as a fleet of watercrafts to collect bottles/debris floating in the River. Check out www.InvictusPaddlingClub.com. The team is continually growing and welcome new members that want to try out the sport for the first time, or just get involved with out environmental projects as well. Everyone is allowed 2 free practices before deciding to join. If you decide to join the team, there is a $10/month membership fee. This is a non-profit team and those fee's help pay for the monthly boat storage at Rick's on the River, Club dragon boat paddles, life jackets, and insurance.
data.how_to_find_us: www.InvictusPaddlingClub.com
