data.description:
This is your chance to visit Switzerland's largest colony of Northern Lapwing birds during a guided tour from the Swiss Ornithological Institute! Be sure to bring binoculars, scopes and a sense of adventure, we are sure to learn a lot about the birds of Switzerland and see many of them ourselves with very knowledgeable guides.

The Swiss Ornithological Institute is a non-profit foundation sponsored by the public. They have a strong volunteer following as do we, which they use to achieve some very meaningful results for bird conservation in Switzerland. Lucky for us, they have kindly offered our group the chance to take a tour to see some of Switzerland's rarest and beautiful birds. This will be followed by lunch and a trip to the Institute's visitor centre. The entire day is free including the tour, but if you would like to join the group at the visitor's centre there is a 10 CHF entry fee (kindly reduced from 15!!).

Meeting point of the Basel group:
To meet us, please come at 8:10 am to staircases down to platform 7 at Basel central station (Basel SBB) with a train ticket to Wauwill so that we can board the 8:28 train to Wauwill. We will return on the train from Sempach after 5 p.m. back to Basel.
If you want to go directly to Wauwill, please contact the organisers to confirm the meeting time and place there.

Please note travel time is further than most of our events but we are sure you won't be disappointed. This means you should expect to be away for a full day. Please also bring a prepared lunch or cash as we will stop somewhere for lunch as well as a water bottle, sun protection and suitable shoes.

We have done events this distance from Zurich before with great attendances and as such we will be trialling this event. If you have any interest in attending the event or that the distance prevented you from going please contact us and let us know. Alternatively please RSVP with plenty of time to let us know what kind of numbers to expect. This will help us to plan better events for you in the near future :))

Can't wait to see you there!!
data.how_to_find_us: 8:15, on top near the starcases down to platform 7, Basel  Central Station (Basel SBB)

Please note travel time is further than most of our events but we are sure you won't be disappointed. This means you should expect to be away for a full day. Please also bring a prepared lunch or cash as we will stop somewhere for lunch as well as a water bottle, sun protection and suitable shoes.

Please RSVP with plenty of time to let us know what kind of numbers to expect. This will help us to plan a great day for you :))

Can't wait to see you there!!

PLEASE READ THIS ENTIRE SECTION TO SEE HOW THIS WORKS:

*** What is TangoTab? ***
TangoTab isn’t a sandwich event, but we love bringing people together to make an impact in their own community. We do that through our Feed The City events, but through TangoTab you can make an even bigger impact and it won’t cost you a cent. TangoTab is a mobile app that you use to find and check-in at restaurants. Every time you check-in at a restaurant on the app, TangoTab provides a free meal to a person in need, locally. DOWNLOAD THE TANGOTAB APP HERE > Download.TangoTab.com

*** How does Feed The City work? ***
Please arrive between 8:30 am and 9:00 am. We will begin PROMPTLY at 9 am.

Who Can Attend: Anyone is at our events! We make this a fun atmosphere for all ages. Remember, you are responsible for anyone under 18y/o that is in your group.

How to Dress: We would love if you wore orange (but not required), make sure your hair is pulled back, so it doesn't hang in your face or wear a ball cap, wear anything you can get bleach spots on.

*** WHAT TO BRING ***

We request that each person attending is You can bring any of the items in any combination, but this is what we recommend...

• 3 Packs of Meat: Please try to make this turkey, chicken or ham; Unfortunately, we cannot accept any meat from the deli counter

• 3 packs - 16 slices each of cheese (no spicy cheese please!)

• 4 Loaves of bread: Try to find a loaf that has 20 slices (not including the ends); Btw we definitely prefer wheat

• 1 Mustard - plain yellow

• 1 bag of Halos, Cuties or tangerines

• 1-2 bags of chips

• 1 - 100 ct. of Sandwich Bags (make sure they zip)

PLEASE TRY TO BRING AN EQUAL AMOUNT OF MEAT, CHEESE & BREAD. Example: If you bring enough slices of cheese for 72 sandwiches, bring enough meat and bread for 72 sandwiches.

REMEMBER, AT THE END OF THE DAY WE WANT TO PRODUCE QUALITY OVER QUANTITY. Please focus on the product you are buying and not just the amount.

data.description:
Fellow Atheists, it's time to do the LA Food Bank again!

Location Note: **Please review this info a day or two before, because sometimes they use another site in the same vicinity and they let us know a few days before.

Location: Usually at Los Angeles Regional Food Bank located at 1734 E. 41st Street, Los Angeles, CA 90058. Street and on-site parking is available. It's best to park on the street and not in their parking lot because it's easier to leave at the end. I usually have no problem finding street parking. You may have to walk a little. Directions at https://drive.google.com/file/d/1NrgZiUD3m_bObOpJaZlEHiiXFcmcp38U/view?usp=sharing

Volunteer Project: Come on down with fellow atheists -- and other L.A. Works volunteers -- to sort, stack and shelve valuable food to distribute to the hungry throughout Los Angeles. Make someone's day, or dinner!

Registration is from 8:30 am to 9:00 am – volunteer project starts at 9:00 am to 12:00 pm. Please bring a signed release form on your day of service.

Release form: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1E75lQlubyyeG07mEFpHGjSZukqI1liCt/view?usp=sharing Minimum age requirement to volunteer is 14 years old, sorry no exceptions. All volunteers that are UNDER 18 years old are required to bring proof of age with picture ID (school ID, state ID, passport, or birth certificate). There is also a Image Release Form that I will send in the email before. L.A. Regional FoodBank provides food support to numerous community agencies serving Los Angeles, ranging from large homeless shelters that feed hundreds of people a day to small daycare programs. It is the second largest foodbank operating in the United States.

Accessibility: L.A. Works firmly believes that we strengthen the social fabric of our community by involving all in service. If you feel you need accommodations to participate in this project please let me know

Dress Code: Safety requirements include: no open-toe/open-heel shoes or high heels. We recommend casual attire (jeans, t-shirt, light sweater, & tennis shoes) Note: Be sure to bring something warm, because one time we sorted food in a much cooler part of the warehouse. We don't know where they will ask us to help!

data.description:
Hi.  If you are using the Meetup mobile app on your phone, look down a few lines below and tap the red-colored "Read more" to expand the description.

TAP THIS ---------

If you are using a computer or laptop/notebook, then you should be fine.

Okay, everybody should now be able to see the full description on their screen.

Reminder for everyone:  If Meetup sends too many emails, then look at the bottom of their email and click Unsubscribe or Manage your settings or account page.

Recommended for anyone new to this group or volunteering for the first time: 

www.meetup.com/SoCalVolunteers/events/[masked]

____________________________________________

Throughout Southern California, food is given for free to people who might be struggling (e.g. unemployed, disabled, homeless, low-income families, seniors on fixed incomes, etc.).

Individuals, food banks, markets/grocery stores, food manufacturers, restaurants, farmers, and others donate food to partner agencies such as soup kitchens, food pantries, churches, and other charities & non-profits for reaching people in need of food.

Caveat:  Some distributions occur at churches.  I could be wrong, but my conjecture is most food distributions don't involve proselytizing.  If anyone is atheist, agnostic, anti-religion, non-religious, Jewish, Muslim, or of a different faith...please know I always ask the respective church group before posting if they allow anyone to participate. 

If you see this event here, then it should mean they are receptive of everyone outside their church group who wants to help (age requirements of kids/minors might apply for some).

Also, if this location (or date/time) is not convenient for you, scroll to the bottom of this description for info on how to find other food distributions.

____________________________________________

All food distributions differ.  Each group might do things differently and have unique rules/restrictions. 

In general, examples of tasks include setting up tables, unloading/unboxing the food donations, neatly organizing and placing food donations on tables, helping with passing out food, assisting with the clients in line, registration/check-in, and clean-up.

Some food distributions are outdoors...while some might be indoors.

Some people might prefer to avoid events related to the homeless or anything involve cooking or getting dirty...so in general, food distributions are another option of volunteer events to choose from.

Plus, this can be a great way to meet people (the other volunteers) who live near you compared to other meetup events that are far and you might not see the other volunteers again.  Many people who volunteer are friendly, so this can be an effective way to meet people and make new friends in your area.

____________________________________________

These photos are from other food distributions.  Not all are identical, so the following pics might give a general idea of what some distributions look like.

www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a[masked]

Photo Source/Credit:  OC Register

Photo Source/Credit:  OC Register

____________________________________________

Okay...finally, here are the details for this specific food distribution.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a4HpRuAwZ0s

www.lakewoodfirstumc.org/broken-loaf-food-pantry

"Volunteers can help by assisting clients with their shopping, help in the clothing room, and support serving of refreshments in the refreshment area."

The church address is on Bellflower Blvd.  Parking might be available in their parking lot.  If parking on a street, such as Harvey Way, look for a driveway entrance/exit or alley such as

Look for a metal door that should be open.  It should be near their kitchen or pantry.  If you see other people, ask for the "Captain" (probably the person in charge) and he/she will help you get started on how to help.

Important:  This is automatically posted in this group.  I will try to check the schedule for conflicts with holidays, but in case I forget, please feel free to contact the church to confirm a food pantry event is happening this Saturday.  They are open nearly every Saturday except major holidays.  The church contact info can be found at the bottom of www.lakewoodfirstumc.org/broken-loaf-food-pantry

btw, sometimes events like this are unpredictable...maybe one week they are low on volunteers and another week/month they have a bunch of unexpected volunteers show up (students, another group/company, etc.).  So if they are crowded and have "too many" volunteers, thank you for your patience and understanding with whatever happens.

____________________________________________

If this location is not geographically convenient for you or your schedule.  Other cities throughout SoCal have food distributions that might need volunteers.  Some food distributions occur on weekday mornings.  A few occur on weekday afternoons or evenings.  While some occur on weekends.  So there's a chance you can find one that is near you and fits your availability.

Orange County

Southern California

http://ampleharvest.org/find-pantry

www.homelessshelterdirectory.org/foodbanks/CAfoodbanks.html

data.description:
ALL VOLUNTEERS ARE are now ***REQUIRED*** to sign up for this event at http://centralmarylandvolunteers.mdfoodbank.volunteerhub.com/

The Maryland Food Bank needs an accurate estimate of how many people will be volunteering for this event, so please update your RSVP as soon as possible if you aren't able to make it to this event.

=======================================
IMPORTANT VOLUNTEER INFO:

- Please arrive to the warehouse ON TIME. We can't begin until EVERYONE is at the warehouse.

- Volunteers must commit to working a three-hour shift.

- For safety, volunteers may not wear open-toed shoes or heels.

- Wear clothes that you don't mind getting dirty (which probably won't happen, but it's a possibility). Volunteers should dress comfortably — preferably in jeans, shorts, sweats and t-shirts.

- All volunteers must attend a brief orientation at the beginning of their shift.

- Volunteers must be over the age of 12.

- Volunteers under the age of 18 cannot work on the conveyor belt in the Baltimore warehouse.

Additional volunteer info can be found at the MD Food Bank's website, at https://www.mdfoodbank.org/volunteer/ .

=======================================

The Maryland Food Bank was founded in 1979 to coordinate the procurement and distribution of food donations from manufacturers, wholesalers, retailers and government agencies to organizations providing free food to the state's hungry.

Volunteers usually work on a high-tech conveyor belt in the warehouse, pulling specific types of food from the belt as they pass, and packing the sorted food into 25 - 50-pound boxes. Full boxes are then placed on the Maryland Food Bank's daily menu, available for more than 600 soup kitchens, pantries and shelters across the state to order.

data.name: Maryland Food Bank

data.description:
San José's 5 1/2–acre Municipal Rose Garden, a historic landmark park, is one of the most attractive of its kind in the world today, drawing thousands of visitors each year. The garden is exclusively devoted to shrubs of the rose family and features over 4,000 rose shrubs with 189 varieties represented.

Like many public parks they have limited resources. Please join us on Saturday, July 14th (Community Volunteer Day) to help provide gardening care and basic landscaping for the 3,500 rose bushes. Tasks include, but aren't limited to, deadheading (clipping off spent blooms), weeding, mulching, pruning and planting.

Volunteers are encouraged to bring a filled water bottle, wear closed-toe shoes, hat, dress in layers (long sleeves and pants are recommended to protect against rose thorns), and wear sunscreen. Gloves will be provided but you're welcome to bring your own if you have a pair.

All tools and training will be provided.

If you have any questions, please call/text me (Magesh) at[masked]. If you would like to get in touch with the organizers directly, please contact Mollie Tobias, Volunteer Program Manager, at[masked] or [masked].

NOTE: If you would like to bring a guest, please have them sign up directly through Meetup. By RSVP’ing to this event, you are agreeing to Silicon Valley Volunteers’ waiver policy. Please go to your profile page and say “YES” to the waiver policy after going through it if you had not done so already. Click on “My Profile” at the top right-hand corner to go to your profile and then click “Edit Profile” to agree to the waiver. SVV events are for adults 18 and over only.

Thanks so much for volunteering with SVV!

data.description:
Come to this workshop to learn how to assemble and maintain your own indoor aquaponics garden system using just a few hand tools!

What is aquaponics? An agricultural system where fish and plants are raised symbiotically: fish waste provides nutrients to plants, while plants filter the water for fish. Benefits of aquaponics include year-round growing, near-freedom from the need to weed and treat for pests, and fresh fish! Aquaponics can be done indoors, provided there is sufficient natural or artificial light, or outside seasonally.

LOCATION: 19th and Alter Street, Philadelphia, PA

2 options for COST:
A) Participate in guided system assembly (materials provided) and take your garden home: $250.
B) Observe workshop and learn about system maintenance: $25.

*Enjoy Greenstreet Coffee as you build your system!

Email [masked] to reserve a spot or get info about future workshops. He will provide additional details for you to review before confirming your spot. Please title all messages “DIY Aquaponics RSVP”. In the message, please include:
1. If you would like to reserve a spot in this workshop or a future workshop.
2. If you would like to build a system or just observe.

Note from the organizer, Robin: I may not be able to attend this event myself, but the workshop is run by my friend Will Cauffman and I thought it was a great fit for this Meetup. All further inquiries can be made directly to Will. Enjoy!

data.description:
Come out to Minnewaska State Park this Saturday morning and enjoy a day of walking and hiking on carriage roads and trails. Our destination is Rainbow Falls, deep in the woods of the park. We have not had much rain so there may not be much water coming over the falls, but the location is beautiful and the woods are cool.

We will begin at the Lower Awosting parking area and walk 2.5 miles on the Lower Awosting Carriageway to get to the Rainbow Falls trail. We will hike this road first as it has little tree cover so we will be cooler hiking it early in the day. We will then descend into the ravine to see the falls. This section of trail is about .6 miles. We will leave the ravine and take the Upper Awosting Carriageway for about .8 miles to the Blueberry Run Trail. After about .3 miles we will connect with the Mossy Glen Trail and follow the Peters Kill stream for about 1.5 miles back to our cars. This trail is very well shaded and peaceful.

Difficulty: Easy/moderate
Distance: About 5.7 miles
Time: approximately 4-5 hours

Bring at least 2 liters of water, snacks, lunch, an extra layer of clothing, sun screen, bug spray, hat, sun glasses, hiking shoes/boots, personal first aid items and medications.

There is a $10 fee per car to enter the park so carpooling encouraged. Contact each other to do so.

data.name: Hike to Rainbow Falls at Minnewaska State Park

data.description:
Live like a Scout again! For our July Meetup we're combining a helpful, outdoor service project with some fun, fellowship & adventure in the beautiful First State National Historical Park at Beaver Valley - a stone's throw from the PA/DE border. We'll be gathering in the morning to help the park with much-needed trail maintenance & preservation. Then after a tasty & refreshing picnic lunch we'll be offering hiking, biking, fishing, and kayaking to all those looking to add some adventure to their day of service. Come join us, bring the family & make some new friends, support the park, get dirty & have some outdoor fun like only Scouting Alumni know how!

The park staff will be directing us & providing any necessary gear to complete our service project. But come prepared (as a Scout should) with your own rugged clothing & footwear, tick/mosquito repellent, rain poncho, work gloves (if you have them), sunscreen & wide-brimmed hat, and plenty of water. We'll be working during the morning only, with the rest of the day to enjoy the park as you wish - or you can go home after the project is complete....your call.

And don't worry - we'll have restrooms on site.

After the project we'll have a picnic lunch, so feel free to bring coolers with whatever you like - which you can keep in your vehicle until lunchtime. No alcohol permitted, and no grilling will be available. But bring whatever else you'd like to munch on & refresh with.

Then the park is yours. 18 miles of trails (hike or bike) in the beautiful Brandywine Valley. Historic Quaker Settlement ruins. And the waters of the Brandywine Creek beckon your fishing rod or kayak. Or you can simply enjoy the great outdoors - it's nature out the wazoo and yours to explore.

And come ready to meet your fellow Scouting Alumni Meetup members and make some new friends, too. This will be our first major outing - the first of many - and we'd love to build a fun & vibrant group that's committed to community service, outdoor adventure, and friendship & fellowship. And we can only do it with your participation. We're looking forward to seeing you!
data.how_to_find_us: Meet by the black Honda Insight in the Smith Bridge parking area (just 0.3 miles south of 199 Brandywine Creek Road, corner of Beaver Dam Rd & Brandywine Creek Rd), and look for Organizer Dave Holland (215-868-9696) in white Scouting Alumni t-shirt.
data.name: Service Project + Outdoor Adventure = July's Scouting Alumni Meetup!!

PREPARE TO BE INSPIRED~
A Permaculture Design Course That Works With You!
Come When You Can | Start When You Can | Pay When You Can

Many students express their deep desire to take a Permaculture Design Course but cannot due to limitations such as finances, time, and family obligations. We have listened and have designed a Permaculture Design Course that harmonizes with these hurdles and makes learning permaculture truly accessible.

Our format makes this course very accessible for learning permaculture and in obtaining very valuable hands on permaculture experience, as well as getting your permaculture design certification.

SOME OF THE IMMEDIATE PERKS:
Come When You Can

This course will integrate into your daily life as it runs twice, continuously throughout the year. We aim for every second weekend of the month but may change which weekends in presence of a major event or holiday. This allows for a “Come When You Can” model where you are never under any pressure to feel rushed or crammed to fit the course into your daily life.

The course runs in it’s entirety 2 times a year. One starts in January and the other in July. Take as long as you want to finish the course (years if needed but not recommended) and come any day of the course. If you cannot start on day 1, then a Free Intro Into Permaculture Class (that is given every Friday evening before each weekend of the course) is necessary to start on any other day of the course.

Flexible Payment – Pay Course Entirety or Per Weekend

No longer will you HAVE to come up with all of the funds to pay for the Permaculture Design Course all at once. This Permaculture Design Course format lifts the burden off of us (on certain levels) which in turn will lift the financial burden off of you. If you have the funds all at once – great pay the course in full and get a considerable discount by doing so. If you would like to pay by the weekend that is great too!

Build Relationships

Most Permaculture Design Courses run for 2 weeks straight. This is a great submersion experience and we still offer these kinds of courses. However, what they lack is the long term relationships that are made with seeing the same faces and making strong connections with your peers and teachers. Permaculture IS about relationships and this format harnesses that power.

Mature Kids Can Come Free

We would love to run day care but we just are not staffed to do so. But your child/children ages 12-17 can come for free. Our staff may interview your kid/s too to help in making our Permaculture for Orphans Program the best it can be. You never know they might learn something too.

What is Permaculture?
Permaculture, is a design system that works with nature to help provide for all your human needs, and designed to benefit all life on the planet. Once established it creates a time-rich environment where people can go to a place of employment because they want to, not because they have to.

A vast array of different disciplines are learned through Permaculture. Since the range of topics are so vast we offer additional workshops and courses for very in-depth specialized education, experience, and training.

Topics and disciplines covered in Permaculture:
Making a Change
Architecture
Soil Biology
Regenerative Gardening & Farming
Urban Permaculture
Earthworks
Animal Husbandry
Climatology
Aquaculture
Nutrition and Natural Healing
Community and Anthropology

data.description:
Clement Waters is an environmental advocacy organization committed to helping one neighborhood at a time maximize the benefits that nature can bring into a community.

The project features a raised bed food garden and walking trails throughout the forest where native Missouri edibles are marked for education and snacking.

When trails are present in a neighborhood, as the Annie E. Casey Foundation has studied & discovered, it transforms a community. When people feel safe getting out, they are more active. They make more engaging connections with their neighbors. We share that hope with the residents of Gregory Ridge neighborhood. Join us in providing a place where families and friends gather, where people can get a bit of exercise in peace without fear, and where food grows at every turn.

Bring your can-do spirit! Be sure to dress to get dirty! Bring your outdoor work gloves, and water bottle.

***Attire -- Please dress comfortably and be prepared to get dirty! Be sure to wear sturdy shoes as the ground is a little rugged. You may also want to wear a hat of some kind as we will be in the sun as well as under forested trees.

***Parking -- You can park along the street on Jackson or across the street from the trail head at the school.

***All ages welcome, but those under 16 must be accompanied by an adult.

Day of: If you have any questions, please feel free to contact Joni K at (913)[masked].

data.description:
You must RSVP at www.readingtokids.org

Reading to Kids is a grassroots organization dedicated to inspiring underserved children with a love of reading, thereby enriching their lives and opportunities for success in the future.  To this end, Reading to Kids gathers on average 825 children and 349 volunteers at reading clubs on the second Saturday of every month at eight Los Angeles elementary schools.

At the monthly reading clubs, pairs of volunteers read aloud to small groups of children, while their parents receive training on how to encourage their children to read at home.  Kids, parents, teachers, and school libraries receive book donations at the end of the reading clubs.  These are important donations, as 60 percent of low-income homes do not have age-appropriate reading materials for children.

Since its inception in 1999, Reading to Kids has given more than 144,800 prize books to children who attend the reading clubs, donated more than 26,000 hardcover books to school libraries, and our volunteers have spent over 171,000 hours reading to kids.  Click here to see our entry on Wikipedia.

There is no long-term commitment.  Once you register, you can decide how often to volunteer.  Whether it's every month, or once a year, we always appreciate your time!

*Please indicate at which school you are volunteering in your RSVP!

You must RSVP at www.readingtokids.org

data.description:
***GREAT NEWS***
From the Riverkeeper:
You did it! Yesterday, Eastland announced that they will no longer pursue plans to build 1400 homes within the Julington-Durbin Preserve, in exchange for property on Black Hammock Island.

In addition, the developer is now working with the Florida Department of Environmental Protection to potentially sell the Black Hammock Island property to the state for conservation.

While the Preserve appears to be safe for now, we cannot rest on our laurels. With the rapid growth that is occurring across the state and our watershed, there will only be more pressure in the future to develop our conservation lands.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Let's celebrate for now, but remain vigilant in our efforts to safeguard our precious conservation lands, like Julington-Durbin. I hope to see you at the Celebration Rally on July 14!

We need ALL OF YOU to show up to show your opposition to this scandulous land grab of one of our precious parks!

Julington-Durbin Preserve is under threat! The developer who sold the land now wants to build 1,400 homes on 400 acres in the heart of the preserve.

Join St. Johns Riverkeeper and partners (Florida Native Plant Society, Duval Audubon Society, Sierra Club Northeast Florida Group, League of Women Voters Jacksonville First Coast, Public Trust Law, and Fun 4 First Coast Kids) for a public rally and guided trail hikes.

Let’s celebrate this special natural area and what we will lose if it is not preserved. Learn how you can take action and help us Save Julington-Durbin Preserve! #SaveJDPreserve

Public Rally (9am)

Post-Rally Guided Hikes:
Native Plant Hike led by Florida Native Plant Society
Native Bird Hike led by Duval Audubon Society
Kids Nature Scavenger Hunt and Hike led by St. Johns Riverkeeper and Fun 4 First Coast Kids
data.name: CELEBRATE Julington-Durbin Preserve Public Rally

Redundant Reiteration:  Signing up here on Meetup is insufficient.  Signing up with Reading To Kids is necessary.  Each volunteer is specifically assigned a school and grade level.  That means they are counting on each person to attend so they have enough readers for all the kids.

http://readingtokids.org/RSVP/VolRSVPConnect.php

After registering and being assigned a school and grade level, they will provide info on the school (address) and other info/details (where to park, meet, etc.).

Video:  www.youtube.com/watch?v=-oPLDw_Vtg8

____________________________________________

I could be wrong, but based on my limited experience/observation, there are eight schools that participate.

For each school, volunteers are needed for six grade levels (Kindergarten, 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th, & 5th).

Approximately 6 - 8 volunteers help for each grade level respectively.

So each could school could potentially have 40 - 50 volunteers.

You definitely have an opportunity to meet and talk with other volunteers who are assigned the same grade level.

The other volunteers are pretty friendly and vary in age, so you likely can meet someone who is similar to your age.

Volunteers meet with others in their assigned grade level to discuss the book and craft activity.  Every volunteer is assigned a reading partner, so you are guaranteed to meet someone new and you won't be alone with the kids.

In addition to reading books, a craft activity is also usually provided.

It's no surprise this event has many returning and new volunteers, and that it can get full each month.

If anyone enjoys reading and likes kids, this is a pretty fun volunteer opportunity.

data.description:
Want to learn more about California's Coastal Wetlands?

Join us for a Nature Walk and an iNaturalist "Bioblitz" at the Bolsa Chica Ecological Reserve (https://www.wildlife.ca.gov/Lands/Places-to-Visit/Bolsa-Chica-ER)

There are over 5 million citizen scientists who share their observations from the natural world with the scientific community via iNaturalist. It’s easy to do. If you own a camera phone (or a fancy digital camera) you can take pictures and upload them to the iNaturalist community.

To get ready for the BioBlitz:

Download the iNaturalist (https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/inaturalist/id421397028?mt=8) app at the California Academy of Scientists (http://www.calacademy.org/citizen-science)

Then start using the iNaturalist App in your local area. Start by taking pictures of local flora and fauna, and check out what other people are documenting in your area. Click on the Explore Icon at the bottom of the app and see what else is being documented. Click on the Observe Icon to take a picture. Click on the Me Icon to see the pictures you are taking. Click on more, projects, nearby, to see what projects are going on near you.

Check out our observations on iNaturalist at our project: Bolsa Chica Ecological Preserve:

https://www.inaturalist.org/projects/bolsa-chica-ecological-reserve-2018

Then join us every month, 9am-11am.

Hope to see you soon! Cheryl and Dave

data.description:
To get ready for construction of the next segment of the paved Northern Walnut Creek Trail, we will take these steps in the areas likely to be disturbed:

Girdle or uproot every invasive tree we find—mainly ligustrums, but also chinaberry, Chinese pistache, and Chinese tallow. We are starting at the planned site of the creek crossing and working back to the trailhead. Do photo forays to find and identify all the native plants in the area. Bring a smart phone along to do this. We're especially interested in finding native plants that are not easy to obtain from commercial sources. At the appropriate time for each species, gather seeds, cuttings, or transplants—whatever it takes to rescue that plant with the highest rate of success. Plant those seeds, cuttings, and transplants in other areas in the park, so their genetic background will remain available to the original locale. On any given date, we can do one, two, or all three of these activities, depending on the weather and your interests.

Dress for the weather. Bring plenty of water. Long pants are always wise, because whatever we do we will be traipsing through brush.

Hello Everyone!

Once a month, I support sister Theresa by packing my car with donations, extra food, and drinks to bring to the homeless and folks who are waiting to get hired for work in our city.

I invite you to come out, meet the folks we support, and bring your helping hands by serving the food that is provided, bringing donations, chatting with the homeless folks, passing out donations, and sharing your time with us.

We start at the Home Depot on Aurora, then caravan to the Home Depot in Shoreline (1335 N 205th St, Seattle). next to the Home Depot in Everett (11915 Highway 99, Everett), and last stop The Union Gospel Mission (711 Smith Ave, Everett).

You can come to one Home Depot or to all of them. You can join us for all of the stops and meet all the folks that we support.

If you would like to bring a donation of clothing (all sizes of Men and Women, but mostly for Men), underwear, shoes, backpacks, toiletries, sunscreen, etc. Extra food, water bottles, etc. it is optional and appreciated. Please make a comment of what you would like to bring.

On Mondays, Value Village has a color tag special for .99 cents. I buy jeans and shoes on those days to give them to these folks. They appreciate the help we give them.

Feel free to contact me if you have other questions.

Thanks for signing up and for helping to make a difference in someone's life.

Amiga Debbie

data.description:
• What we'll do
JOIN THE MOVEMENT TO PROTECT OUR CHILDREN

Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASA) is seeking volunteers to advocate for children who have been abused or neglected. On any given day, more than 350 children from Middlesex County are living in foster care. Now, more than ever, we need you. A child with a CASA is more likely to find a permanent home, spend less time in foster care, and perform better in school. Champion one of these children from your community and safeguard a child’s well being through advocacy in the court today. What does a CASA do? A CASA is integral in helping the Court in determining the appropriate permanent plan for the child. We ensure abuse and neglect doesn’t continue at the hand’s of the court. A CASA forges a connection with the child/children they are matched with. They build their trust and discover what their needs are. They examine their health and education records and meet with their caregivers, school, therapists and other professionals. Once they identify what the child’s needs are, they write a report and advocate for a child’s needs in court. Our staff and peer coordinators are with you every step of the way to support you and help you succeed. No special skills or specific backgrounds are needed. Advocates must be able to commit to volunteering about 6-8 hours a month, meet with the foster child they are assigned to at least once a month and commit to a case from start to finish, about 1 to 2 years. Training will start February 26th through March 29th. If you are interested in volunteering call (732)[masked], email [masked], or visit www.casaofmiddlesexcounty.org/volunteer for a volunteer application.

• What to bring

• Important to know

data.description:
Habitat KC ReStore accepts donated building materials & resells those items to people in the community for home repair. This reduces waste in the landfills and profits from the store support the housing programs Habitat for Humanity is best known for. Win-win!

Volunteers sort donations, stock inventory and make the stores as tidy as possible during our 3 hour shift. Examples of tasks we might do include sorting trim or tile, measuring blinds, straightening tile or color tabbing paint. While there are some physical demands, we can usually find something for anyone to do.

Closed-toe shoes Required! Come ready to get your hands dirty and wear comfortable clothing you don't mind getting dirty. You may want to bring garden or work gloves if you have them.

AGE REQUIREMENTS: Must be at least 14 years old to volunteer at ReStore. A legal guardian must sign the Release & Waiver of Liability for Minors (http://bit.ly/2iMTVZ6) and have an adult with you. DO NOT bring young children to this event.

Serve KC volunteers every 2nd Saturday at the Habitat KC Waldo location. We'll work for 3 hours starting at 9:30 am and work until 12:30 pm. If you need to leave early please tell the event host. Please be firm in your commitment as space is limited

Fore more information about Habitat ReStore visit their website: www.habitatkc.org/restorekc

WAITLIST: If an event is full volunteers can join the waitlist. If a spot opens up, you are automatically added to the attending list in the order you joined the waitlist. Please remove yourself from the waitlist if you make other plans so the next available person can join in the event of a last minute cancellation.
data.how_to_find_us: Check in at the front desk or look for others near the door from Serve KC.

data.description:
http://vimeo.com/5302326#t=21s

At The Crossroads (http://www.atthecrossroads.org) reaches out to homeless youth at their point of need (street outreach) and works with them to build healthy and fulfilling lives. They provide supplies and counseling to over 200 clients weekly.

https://fundraise.atthecrossroads.org/event/summer-sunday-2018/e181092

Summer SunDay is a half-day fundraising hike up to the East Peak of Mount Tamalpais on Sunday, July 15. Hikers are given the tools and individualized support to reach out to their communities and raise vital funds for At The Crossroads, a nonprofit organization that works with homeless youth and young adults in San Francisco.

There are many positions available throughout the day including:

Office Volunteers (10+ vols) (both heavy lifting and low impact opportunities available) @ The Office - Come spend a day in the office with the staff of ATC helping us prep the last of our hike supplies from about 10am-6pm. You don't have to stay the whole time, but if you could come by for any of it, that would be great! Some tasks will include: preparing the incentives and thank you bags, packing the vans, helping us prepare food, and organizing and labeling supplies.

Food Runners (2 vols) (MUST HAVE CAR) - Help ATC pick up food that our amazing sponsors have graciously donated to our hike. As a food runner, you will be exploring the urban landscape of San Francisco, as well as engaging with some fantastic restaurants and companies. If you are a foodie, this is the task for you. We would have volunteers waiting for you downstairs, so you could just drop off the goods and enjoy the rest of your day!

Sign Placers (8-10 vols) (very physical) @ Mt. Tam - Come spend a beautiful day on Mt. Tam helping us place signs for our hike. You would meet at Mt. Tam at 10 am and the sign placement should take about 4 hours. Armed with the expertise of a veteran sign placer, a handy GPS, and sign supplies, you will embark on the hike and place signs to ensure that our hikers won't get lost the next day. The GPS is preprogrammed with all of the sign placement locations. We are looking for about 10 volunteers who are able to trek up the mountain. You are more than welcome to invite friends to help out!

Please call or email Sharissa Staples for volunteer placement: [masked] or tel:(415)[masked] x103.
data.how_to_find_us: Easy to access from Powell Street Station and Market Street Muni lines.

data.description:
TWO STEPS YOU NEED TO TAKE TO PARTICIPATE

STEP 1: Resister at a Green Team volunteer: http://goo.gl/WRx6jr
You only ever have to register as a volunteer ONCE

STEP 2: Register for this July 14 activity: http://goo.gl/i7xuas

Please always use your own unique email address for all online forms. That's the only way we know who you are.

We'll be at the park volunteering rain or shine

MEETING DETAILS:

We are meeting at the trailhead near Gilpin St and Deer Lake Avenue in Burnaby.
For an interactive google map click: http://goo.gl/Q7xGAK

ABOUT SITE:

Deer Lake Park is situated in a peaceful natural environment that serves as the cultural precinct for the City of Burnaby’s arts and heritage amenities. It's criss-crossed with hiking and walking trails, including a boardwalk along the lake. There are also opportunities for bird-watching and wildlife-viewing in the lake, forest, meadow and marsh areas.

The vegetation natural to the area is temperate rainforest dominated by conifers such as western hemlock, Douglas Fir, and Western Red Cedar.

REDUCE YOUR FOOTPRINT AND USE TRANSIT, BICYCLE or TRANSIT

Transit. To find out the best route from where you are click: http://www.translink.bc.ca

Carpool. Leave a message at the bottom of this page if you need a ride. Don't forget to chip in for gas ($5 for every hour of drive is about right)

Cycle. For a bicycle map click HERE (http://www.translink.ca/en/Getting-Around/Cycling/Cycling-Maps.aspx)

FLOW OF ACTIVITY

• Meet at 9.45am (please don't be late)
• Sign in
• Walk to Site (follow arrows if you're late)
• Remove the invasive plant - Policeman's Helmet (VERY EASY and fun to pull out)
• Volunteer until 1 pm
• Sign out

REGISTER AS A GREEN TEAM VOLUNTEER AHEAD OF TIME ONLINE

• If you haven't yet, register online: http://goo.gl/WRx6jr

WHAT TO BRING:

• Refillable water bottle
• Rain jacket in case it rains. Don't let the rain scare you off!
• If it's sunny bring a hat and sunscreen
• Your own gardening gloves if you prefer them (we provide them otherwise)
• Wear clothes you don't mind getting dirty
• Long sleeves and long pants to protect you from thorny plants and ticks
• Sturdy, comfortable closed toe shoes/boots. Gum boots work too!

WHAT WILL BE PROVIDED TO YOU:

• Gardening gloves if you don't have your own
• Tools
• Refreshments at the break (often juices, fruits, veggies, energy bars and cookies)
• Instruction on what to do. You don't need to have experience to participate!
• An opportunity to meet new people and have a fun experience in a beautiful park!

WHAT HAPPENS AFTERWARDS?

• A volunteer letter emailed to you on request
• Photos taken will be loaded up in a photo album: http://goo.gl/hctXBv
• A summary of how this activity went along with before and after photos will be posted to show what a big impact you've made (we're still looking for a home for where this will go!)

PARTNER FOR THIS ACTIVITY:

We are working with the City of Burnaby: https://www.burnaby.ca

City of Burnaby recognizes the value of partnering with a local charity to increase community engagement, increase civic pride and raise environmental awareness, not to mention increase their capacity to improve their local parks!

OTHER AWESOME GROUPS IN THE AREA:

Byrne Creek Streamkeepers: http://byrnecreek.org
Stoney Creek Environment Committee: http://scec.ca
Burnaby Lake Park Association: http://burnabylakepark.ca

QUESTIONS?

Email [masked]

data.description:
SEED TO STORAGE GARDENING SERIES #7
Preserving the Harvest - Freezing and Drying

Cost: $20-$25/class. A $10 non-refundable deposit is due upon registration.

**PLEASE NOTE: This workshop will be held at a different location than previous classes**

Now that summer is here in full force, our home gardens and farmers markets are have an abundance of fresh, local produce. It’s prime time to preserve the bounty to enjoy throughout the year!

In this class, we will cover two food preservation methods: freezing and drying. Drying is a simple, inexpensive way to preserve foods and is especially useful for creating lightweight snacks and meals for outdoor activities. Discover how to freeze to maximize nutrient quality (and not have soggy beans!). Learn different techniques to best freeze or dehydrate fruits, vegetables, and herbs. Participants will receive recipes, sample various preserved foods, and take samples to dry at home.

ABOUT THE SEED TO STORAGE GARDENING SERIES
We are excited to have Mary Wicklund present this 12-part series covering all aspects of gardening . . . from site selection and garden design, to preserving your bountiful harvest!

These hands-on workshops will be held at an Amesbury home with an abundant backyard food garden, which provides an opportunity to follow it's progress throughout the season. Information will be provided to apply what is learned in your own garden, and there will be time to check in with question during every class. Be ready to get your hands dirty!

Because the lessons (and gardening) build on the previous classes, we recommend attending the entire series. All classes will run from 10 AM to Noon.

• Sat, Mar 10 Garden Design/Maximizing your Harvest
• Sat, Mar 17 Seed Starting
• Sat, Apr 14 Direct Seeding/Transplanting/Cold hardy plants
• Sat, Apr 28 Composting/Vermicomposting
• Sat, May 19 Tender Crops & Rain Barrels
• Sat, June 9 Plant Guilds/Garden Question Check-In
• Sat, Jul 14 Preserving the Harvest - Freezing/Drying
• Sat, Aug 25 Preserving the Harvest - Canning
• Sat, Sep 8 Preserving the Harvest - Fermentation
• Sat, Sep 29 Seed Saving/Season Extension/First Frost Watch
• Sat, Oct 20 Putting the Garden to Bed/ Root Cellaring
• Sat, Nov 3 Preparing for Next Season - Sheet Mulching & Garlic Planting

ABOUT MARY WICKLUND: Mary Wicklund is a Permaculture Designer, Educator, and Garden Coach. She is a UMaine Master Gardener and UMaine Master Food Preserver. She has grown in spaces ranging from backyard and school gardens to a 50+ member CSA in South Berwick, ME, which focused on growing nutrient dense produce on no-till beds.
data.name: Preserving the Harvest - Freezing and Drying  (SEED TO STORAGE SERIES #7)

data.description:
This coffee is for all long-term survivors (see definition below).

We will be serving breakfast in the kitchen area around 10:30 am. Please let us know if you are interested in volunteering in the kitchen to help with breakfast.

As our coffee social is self-supporting, we kindly request a $5.00 or more donation to help pay for the space, coffee and breakfast.

There is free parking in the Quest Center lot. The TriMet 20 bus will drop you off on the corner of E. Burnside and 28th. Walk one walk block east on Burnside past Whole Foods and you will find us on the left. We will be located behind Quest's main building, next to the parking lot.

Like us on Facebook and share this information with your networks that you think will benefit by joining us.

Long-term survivors include anyone who has been diagnosed HIV+ for 10 or more years, as well as those who are HIV- but whose lives have been affected by HIV/AIDS for 10 or more years. You are also welcome to join us if you are over the age of 50 and HIV+, regardless of your diagnosis date.

All others who are interested in learning more about LKA-PDX may still attend our Saturday coffee socials as a supporter.

We ask that no cologne or perfume be warn, as we want to be mindful of those who have allergies or breathing problems.

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
